text: In my first book I told you, Theophilus, about everything Jesus began to do and teach
speaker: Narrator

text: until the day he was taken up to heaven after giving his chosen apostles further instructions through the Holy Spirit.
speaker: Narrator

text: During the forty days after he suffered and died, he appeared to the apostles from time to time, and he proved to them in many ways that he was actually alive. And he talked to them about the Kingdom of God.
speaker: Narrator

text: Once when he was eating with them, he commanded them, “Do not leave Jerusalem until the Father sends you the gift he promised, as I told you before.
speaker: Narrator

text: John baptized with water, but in just a few days you will be baptized with the Holy Spirit.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So when the apostles were with Jesus, they kept asking him, “Lord, has the time come for you to free Israel and restore our kingdom?”
speaker: Narrator

text: He replied, “The Father alone has the authority to set those dates and times, and they are not for you to know.
speaker: Narrator

text: But you will receive power when the Holy Spirit comes upon you. And you will be my witnesses, telling people about me everywhere—in Jerusalem, throughout Judea, in Samaria, and to the ends of the earth.”
speaker: Narrator

text: After saying this, he was taken up into a cloud while they were watching, and they could no longer see him.
speaker: Narrator

text: As they strained to see him rising into heaven, two white-robed men suddenly stood among them.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Men of Galilee,” they said, “why are you standing here staring into heaven? Jesus has been taken from you into heaven, but someday he will return from heaven in the same way you saw him go!”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the apostles returned to Jerusalem from the Mount of Olives, a distance of half a mile.
speaker: Narrator

text:
When they arrived, they went to the upstairs room of the house where they were staying.
Here are the names of those who were present: Peter, John, James, Andrew, Philip, Thomas, Bartholomew, Matthew, James (son of Alphaeus), Simon (the zealot), and Judas (son of James).
speaker: Narrator

text: They all met together and were constantly united in prayer, along with Mary the mother of Jesus, several other women, and the brothers of Jesus.
speaker: Narrator

text: During this time, when about 120 believers were together in one place, Peter stood up and addressed them.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Brothers,” he said, “the Scriptures had to be fulfilled concerning Judas, who guided those who arrested Jesus. This was predicted long ago by the Holy Spirit, speaking through King David.
speaker: Narrator

text: Judas was one of us and shared in the ministry with us.”
speaker: Narrator

text: (Judas had bought a field with the money he received for his treachery. Falling headfirst there, his body split open, spilling out all his intestines.
speaker: Narrator

text: The news of his death spread to all the people of Jerusalem, and they gave the place the Aramaic name Akeldama, which means “Field of Blood.”)
speaker: Narrator

text: Peter continued, “This was written in the book of Psalms, where it says, ‘Let his home become desolate, with no one living in it.’ It also says, ‘Let someone else take his position.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “So now we must choose a replacement for Judas from among the men who were with us the entire time we were traveling with the Lord Jesus—
speaker: Narrator

text: from the time he was baptized by John until the day he was taken from us. Whoever is chosen will join us as a witness of Jesus’ resurrection.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So they nominated two men: Joseph called Barsabbas (also known as Justus) and Matthias.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then they all prayed, “O Lord, you know every heart. Show us which of these men you have chosen
speaker: Narrator

text: as an apostle to replace Judas in this ministry, for he has deserted us and gone where he belongs.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then they cast lots, and Matthias was selected to become an apostle with the other eleven.
speaker: Narrator

text: On the day of Pentecost all the believers were meeting together in one place.
speaker: Narrator

text: Suddenly, there was a sound from heaven like the roaring of a mighty windstorm, and it filled the house where they were sitting.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then, what looked like flames or tongues of fire appeared and settled on each of them.
speaker: Narrator

text: And everyone present was filled with the Holy Spirit and began speaking in other languages, as the Holy Spirit gave them this ability.
speaker: Narrator

text: At that time there were devout Jews from every nation living in Jerusalem.
speaker: Narrator

text: When they heard the loud noise, everyone came running, and they were bewildered to hear their own languages being spoken by the believers.
speaker: Narrator

text: They were completely amazed. “How can this be?” they exclaimed. “These people are all from Galilee,
speaker: Narrator

text: and yet we hear them speaking in our own native languages!
speaker: Narrator

text: Here we are—Parthians, Medes, Elamites, people from Mesopotamia, Judea, Cappadocia, Pontus, the province of Asia,
speaker: Narrator

text: Phrygia, Pamphylia, Egypt, and the areas of Libya around Cyrene, visitors from Rome
speaker: Narrator

text: (both Jews and converts to Judaism), Cretans, and Arabs. And we all hear these people speaking in our own languages about the wonderful things God has done!”
speaker: Narrator

text: They stood there amazed and perplexed. “What can this mean?” they asked each other.
speaker: Narrator

text: But others in the crowd ridiculed them, saying, “They’re just drunk, that’s all!”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Peter stepped forward with the eleven other apostles and shouted to the crowd, “Listen carefully, all of you, fellow Jews and residents of Jerusalem! Make no mistake about this.
speaker: Narrator

text: These people are not drunk, as some of you are assuming. Nine o’clock in the morning is much too early for that.
speaker: Narrator

text: No, what you see was predicted long ago by the prophet Joel:
speaker: Narrator

text:
‘In the last days,’ God says,
    ‘I will pour out my Spirit upon all people.
Your sons and daughters will prophesy.
    Your young men will see visions,
    and your old men will dream dreams.
speaker: Narrator

text:
In those days I will pour out my Spirit
    even on my servants—men and women alike—
    and they will prophesy.
speaker: Narrator

text:
And I will cause wonders in the heavens above
    and signs on the earth below—
    blood and fire and clouds of smoke.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The sun will become dark,
    and the moon will turn blood red
    before that great and glorious day of the Lord arrives.
speaker: Narrator

text:
But everyone who calls on the name of the Lord
    will be saved.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “People of Israel, listen! God publicly endorsed Jesus the Nazarene by doing powerful miracles, wonders, and signs through him, as you well know.
speaker: Narrator

text: But God knew what would happen, and his prearranged plan was carried out when Jesus was betrayed. With the help of lawless Gentiles, you nailed him to a cross and killed him.
speaker: Narrator

text: But God released him from the horrors of death and raised him back to life, for death could not keep him in its grip.
speaker: Narrator

text:
King David said this about him:
‘I see that the Lord is always with me.
    I will not be shaken, for he is right beside me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
No wonder my heart is glad,
    and my tongue shouts his praises!
    My body rests in hope.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For you will not leave my soul among the dead
    or allow your Holy One to rot in the grave.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You have shown me the way of life,
    and you will fill me with the joy of your presence.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “Dear brothers, think about this! You can be sure that the patriarch David wasn’t referring to himself, for he died and was buried, and his tomb is still here among us.
speaker: Narrator

text: But he was a prophet, and he knew God had promised with an oath that one of David’s own descendants would sit on his throne.
speaker: Narrator

text: David was looking into the future and speaking of the Messiah’s resurrection. He was saying that God would not leave him among the dead or allow his body to rot in the grave.
speaker: Narrator

text: “God raised Jesus from the dead, and we are all witnesses of this.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now he is exalted to the place of highest honor in heaven, at God’s right hand. And the Father, as he had promised, gave him the Holy Spirit to pour out upon us, just as you see and hear today.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For David himself never ascended into heaven, yet he said,
‘The Lord said to my Lord,
    “Sit in the place of honor at my right hand
speaker: Narrator

text:
until I humble your enemies,
    making them a footstool under your feet.”’
speaker: Narrator

text: “So let everyone in Israel know for certain that God has made this Jesus, whom you crucified, to be both Lord and Messiah!”
speaker: Narrator

text: Peter’s words pierced their hearts, and they said to him and to the other apostles, “Brothers, what should we do?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Peter replied, “Each of you must repent of your sins and turn to God, and be baptized in the name of Jesus Christ for the forgiveness of your sins. Then you will receive the gift of the Holy Spirit.
speaker: Narrator

text: This promise is to you, to your children, and to those far away—all who have been called by the Lord our God.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Peter continued preaching for a long time, strongly urging all his listeners, “Save yourselves from this crooked generation!”
speaker: Narrator

text: Those who believed what Peter said were baptized and added to the church that day—about 3,000 in all.
speaker: Narrator

text: All the believers devoted themselves to the apostles’ teaching, and to fellowship, and to sharing in meals (including the Lord’s Supper), and to prayer.
speaker: Narrator

text: A deep sense of awe came over them all, and the apostles performed many miraculous signs and wonders.
speaker: Narrator

text: And all the believers met together in one place and shared everything they had.
speaker: Narrator

text: They sold their property and possessions and shared the money with those in need.
speaker: Narrator

text: They worshiped together at the Temple each day, met in homes for the Lord’s Supper, and shared their meals with great joy and generosity—
speaker: Narrator

text: all the while praising God and enjoying the goodwill of all the people. And each day the Lord added to their fellowship those who were being saved.
speaker: Narrator

text: Peter and John went to the Temple one afternoon to take part in the three o’clock prayer service.
speaker: Narrator

text: As they approached the Temple, a man lame from birth was being carried in. Each day he was put beside the Temple gate, the one called the Beautiful Gate, so he could beg from the people going into the Temple.
speaker: Narrator

text: When he saw Peter and John about to enter, he asked them for some money.
speaker: Narrator

text: Peter and John looked at him intently, and Peter said, “Look at us!”
speaker: Narrator

text: The lame man looked at them eagerly, expecting some money.
speaker: Narrator

text: But Peter said, “I don’t have any silver or gold for you. But I’ll give you what I have. In the name of Jesus Christ the Nazarene, get up and walk!”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Peter took the lame man by the right hand and helped him up. And as he did, the man’s feet and ankles were instantly healed and strengthened.
speaker: Narrator

text: He jumped up, stood on his feet, and began to walk! Then, walking, leaping, and praising God, he went into the Temple with them.
speaker: Narrator

text: All the people saw him walking and heard him praising God.
speaker: Narrator

text: When they realized he was the lame beggar they had seen so often at the Beautiful Gate, they were absolutely astounded!
speaker: Narrator

text: They all rushed out in amazement to Solomon’s Colonnade, where the man was holding tightly to Peter and John.
speaker: Narrator

text: Peter saw his opportunity and addressed the crowd. “People of Israel,” he said, “what is so surprising about this? And why stare at us as though we had made this man walk by our own power or godliness?
speaker: Narrator

text: For it is the God of Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob—the God of all our ancestors—who has brought glory to his servant Jesus by doing this. This is the same Jesus whom you handed over and rejected before Pilate, despite Pilate’s decision to release him.
speaker: Narrator

text: You rejected this holy, righteous one and instead demanded the release of a murderer.
speaker: Narrator

text: You killed the author of life, but God raised him from the dead. And we are witnesses of this fact!
speaker: Narrator

text: “Through faith in the name of Jesus, this man was healed—and you know how crippled he was before. Faith in Jesus’ name has healed him before your very eyes.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Friends, I realize that what you and your leaders did to Jesus was done in ignorance.
speaker: Narrator

text: But God was fulfilling what all the prophets had foretold about the Messiah—that he must suffer these things.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now repent of your sins and turn to God, so that your sins may be wiped away.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then times of refreshment will come from the presence of the Lord, and he will again send you Jesus, your appointed Messiah.
speaker: Narrator

text: For he must remain in heaven until the time for the final restoration of all things, as God promised long ago through his holy prophets.
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses said, ‘The Lord your God will raise up for you a Prophet like me from among your own people. Listen carefully to everything he tells you.’
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Moses said, ‘Anyone who will not listen to that Prophet will be completely cut off from God’s people.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “Starting with Samuel, every prophet spoke about what is happening today.
speaker: Narrator

text: You are the children of those prophets, and you are included in the covenant God promised to your ancestors. For God said to Abraham, ‘Through your descendants all the families on earth will be blessed.’
speaker: Narrator

text: When God raised up his servant, Jesus, he sent him first to you people of Israel, to bless you by turning each of you back from your sinful ways.”
speaker: Narrator

text: While Peter and John were speaking to the people, they were confronted by the priests, the captain of the Temple guard, and some of the Sadducees.
speaker: Narrator

text: These leaders were very disturbed that Peter and John were teaching the people that through Jesus there is a resurrection of the dead.
speaker: Narrator

text: They arrested them and, since it was already evening, put them in jail until morning.
speaker: Narrator

text: But many of the people who heard their message believed it, so the number of men who believed now totaled about 5,000.
speaker: Narrator

text: The next day the council of all the rulers and elders and teachers of religious law met in Jerusalem.
speaker: Narrator

text: Annas the high priest was there, along with Caiaphas, John, Alexander, and other relatives of the high priest.
speaker: Narrator

text: They brought in the two disciples and demanded, “By what power, or in whose name, have you done this?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Peter, filled with the Holy Spirit, said to them, “Rulers and elders of our people,
speaker: Narrator

text: are we being questioned today because we’ve done a good deed for a crippled man? Do you want to know how he was healed?
speaker: Narrator

text: Let me clearly state to all of you and to all the people of Israel that he was healed by the powerful name of Jesus Christ the Nazarene, the man you crucified but whom God raised from the dead.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For Jesus is the one referred to in the Scriptures, where it says,
‘The stone that you builders rejected
    has now become the cornerstone.’
speaker: Narrator

text: There is salvation in no one else! God has given no other name under heaven by which we must be saved.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The members of the council were amazed when they saw the boldness of Peter and John, for they could see that they were ordinary men with no special training in the Scriptures. They also recognized them as men who had been with Jesus.
speaker: Narrator

text: But since they could see the man who had been healed standing right there among them, there was nothing the council could say.
speaker: Narrator

text: So they ordered Peter and John out of the council chamber and conferred among themselves.
speaker: Narrator

text: “What should we do with these men?” they asked each other. “We can’t deny that they have performed a miraculous sign, and everybody in Jerusalem knows about it.
speaker: Narrator

text: But to keep them from spreading their propaganda any further, we must warn them not to speak to anyone in Jesus’ name again.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So they called the apostles back in and commanded them never again to speak or teach in the name of Jesus.
speaker: Narrator

text: But Peter and John replied, “Do you think God wants us to obey you rather than him?
speaker: Narrator

text: We cannot stop telling about everything we have seen and heard.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The council then threatened them further, but they finally let them go because they didn’t know how to punish them without starting a riot. For everyone was praising God
speaker: Narrator

text: for this miraculous sign—the healing of a man who had been lame for more than forty years.
speaker: Narrator

text: As soon as they were freed, Peter and John returned to the other believers and told them what the leading priests and elders had said.
speaker: Narrator

text: When they heard the report, all the believers lifted their voices together in prayer to God: “O Sovereign Lord, Creator of heaven and earth, the sea, and everything in them—
speaker: Narrator

text:
you spoke long ago by the Holy Spirit through our ancestor David, your servant, saying,
‘Why were the nations so angry?
    Why did they waste their time with futile plans?
speaker: Narrator

text:
The kings of the earth prepared for battle;
    the rulers gathered together
against the Lord
    and against his Messiah.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “In fact, this has happened here in this very city! For Herod Antipas, Pontius Pilate the governor, the Gentiles, and the people of Israel were all united against Jesus, your holy servant, whom you anointed.
speaker: Narrator

text: But everything they did was determined beforehand according to your will.
speaker: Narrator

text: And now, O Lord, hear their threats, and give us, your servants, great boldness in preaching your word.
speaker: Narrator

text: Stretch out your hand with healing power; may miraculous signs and wonders be done through the name of your holy servant Jesus.”
speaker: Narrator

text: After this prayer, the meeting place shook, and they were all filled with the Holy Spirit. Then they preached the word of God with boldness.
speaker: Narrator

text: All the believers were united in heart and mind. And they felt that what they owned was not their own, so they shared everything they had.
speaker: Narrator

text: The apostles testified powerfully to the resurrection of the Lord Jesus, and God’s great blessing was upon them all.
speaker: Narrator

text: There were no needy people among them, because those who owned land or houses would sell them
speaker: Narrator

text: and bring the money to the apostles to give to those in need.
speaker: Narrator

text: For instance, there was Joseph, the one the apostles nicknamed Barnabas (which means “Son of Encouragement”). He was from the tribe of Levi and came from the island of Cyprus.
speaker: Narrator

text: He sold a field he owned and brought the money to the apostles.
speaker: Narrator

text: But there was a certain man named Ananias who, with his wife, Sapphira, sold some property.
speaker: Narrator

text: He brought part of the money to the apostles, claiming it was the full amount. With his wife’s consent, he kept the rest.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Peter said, “Ananias, why have you let Satan fill your heart? You lied to the Holy Spirit, and you kept some of the money for yourself.
speaker: Narrator

text: The property was yours to sell or not sell, as you wished. And after selling it, the money was also yours to give away. How could you do a thing like this? You weren’t lying to us but to God!”
speaker: Narrator

text: As soon as Ananias heard these words, he fell to the floor and died. Everyone who heard about it was terrified.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then some young men got up, wrapped him in a sheet, and took him out and buried him.
speaker: Narrator

text: About three hours later his wife came in, not knowing what had happened.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Peter asked her, “Was this the price you and your husband received for your land?”
“Yes,” she replied, “that was the price.”
speaker: Narrator

text: And Peter said, “How could the two of you even think of conspiring to test the Spirit of the Lord like this? The young men who buried your husband are just outside the door, and they will carry you out, too.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Instantly, she fell to the floor and died. When the young men came in and saw that she was dead, they carried her out and buried her beside her husband.
speaker: Narrator

text: Great fear gripped the entire church and everyone else who heard what had happened.
speaker: Narrator

text: The apostles were performing many miraculous signs and wonders among the people. And all the believers were meeting regularly at the Temple in the area known as Solomon’s Colonnade.
speaker: Narrator

text: But no one else dared to join them, even though all the people had high regard for them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Yet more and more people believed and were brought to the Lord—crowds of both men and women.
speaker: Narrator

text: As a result of the apostles’ work, sick people were brought out into the streets on beds and mats so that Peter’s shadow might fall across some of them as he went by.
speaker: Narrator

text: Crowds came from the villages around Jerusalem, bringing their sick and those possessed by evil spirits, and they were all healed.
speaker: Narrator

text: The high priest and his officials, who were Sadducees, were filled with jealousy.
speaker: Narrator

text: They arrested the apostles and put them in the public jail.
speaker: Narrator

text: But an angel of the Lord came at night, opened the gates of the jail, and brought them out. Then he told them,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Go to the Temple and give the people this message of life!”
speaker: Narrator

text:
So at daybreak the apostles entered the Temple, as they were told, and immediately began teaching.
When the high priest and his officials arrived, they convened the high council—the full assembly of the elders of Israel. Then they sent for the apostles to be brought from the jail for trial.
speaker: Narrator

text: But when the Temple guards went to the jail, the men were gone. So they returned to the council and reported,
speaker: Narrator

text: “The jail was securely locked, with the guards standing outside, but when we opened the gates, no one was there!”
speaker: Narrator

text: When the captain of the Temple guard and the leading priests heard this, they were perplexed, wondering where it would all end.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then someone arrived with startling news: “The men you put in jail are standing in the Temple, teaching the people!”
speaker: Narrator

text: The captain went with his Temple guards and arrested the apostles, but without violence, for they were afraid the people would stone them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then they brought the apostles before the high council, where the high priest confronted them.
speaker: Narrator

text: “We gave you strict orders never again to teach in this man’s name!” he said. “Instead, you have filled all Jerusalem with your teaching about him, and you want to make us responsible for his death!”
speaker: Narrator

text: But Peter and the apostles replied, “We must obey God rather than any human authority.
speaker: Narrator

text: The God of our ancestors raised Jesus from the dead after you killed him by hanging him on a cross.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then God put him in the place of honor at his right hand as Prince and Savior. He did this so the people of Israel would repent of their sins and be forgiven.
speaker: Narrator

text: We are witnesses of these things and so is the Holy Spirit, who is given by God to those who obey him.”
speaker: Narrator

text: When they heard this, the high council was furious and decided to kill them.
speaker: Narrator

text: But one member, a Pharisee named Gamaliel, who was an expert in religious law and respected by all the people, stood up and ordered that the men be sent outside the council chamber for a while.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he said to his colleagues, “Men of Israel, take care what you are planning to do to these men!
speaker: Narrator

text: Some time ago there was that fellow Theudas, who pretended to be someone great. About 400 others joined him, but he was killed, and all his followers went their various ways. The whole movement came to nothing.
speaker: Narrator

text: After him, at the time of the census, there was Judas of Galilee. He got people to follow him, but he was killed, too, and all his followers were scattered.
speaker: Narrator

text: “So my advice is, leave these men alone. Let them go. If they are planning and doing these things merely on their own, it will soon be overthrown.
speaker: Narrator

text: But if it is from God, you will not be able to overthrow them. You may even find yourselves fighting against God!”
speaker: Narrator

text: The others accepted his advice. They called in the apostles and had them flogged. Then they ordered them never again to speak in the name of Jesus, and they let them go.
speaker: Narrator

text: The apostles left the high council rejoicing that God had counted them worthy to suffer disgrace for the name of Jesus.
speaker: Narrator

text: And every day, in the Temple and from house to house, they continued to teach and preach this message: “Jesus is the Messiah.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But as the believers rapidly multiplied, there were rumblings of discontent. The Greek-speaking believers complained about the Hebrew-speaking believers, saying that their widows were being discriminated against in the daily distribution of food.
speaker: Narrator

text: So the Twelve called a meeting of all the believers. They said, “We apostles should spend our time teaching the word of God, not running a food program.
speaker: Narrator

text: And so, brothers, select seven men who are well respected and are full of the Spirit and wisdom. We will give them this responsibility.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then we apostles can spend our time in prayer and teaching the word.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Everyone liked this idea, and they chose the following: Stephen (a man full of faith and the Holy Spirit), Philip, Procorus, Nicanor, Timon, Parmenas, and Nicolas of Antioch (an earlier convert to the Jewish faith).
speaker: Narrator

text: These seven were presented to the apostles, who prayed for them as they laid their hands on them.
speaker: Narrator

text: So God’s message continued to spread. The number of believers greatly increased in Jerusalem, and many of the Jewish priests were converted, too.
speaker: Narrator

text: Stephen, a man full of God’s grace and power, performed amazing miracles and signs among the people.
speaker: Narrator

text: But one day some men from the Synagogue of Freed Slaves, as it was called, started to debate with him. They were Jews from Cyrene, Alexandria, Cilicia, and the province of Asia.
speaker: Narrator

text: None of them could stand against the wisdom and the Spirit with which Stephen spoke.
speaker: Narrator

text: So they persuaded some men to lie about Stephen, saying, “We heard him blaspheme Moses, and even God.”
speaker: Narrator

text: This roused the people, the elders, and the teachers of religious law. So they arrested Stephen and brought him before the high council.
speaker: Narrator

text: The lying witnesses said, “This man is always speaking against the holy Temple and against the law of Moses.
speaker: Narrator

text: We have heard him say that this Jesus of Nazareth will destroy the Temple and change the customs Moses handed down to us.”
speaker: Narrator

text: At this point everyone in the high council stared at Stephen, because his face became as bright as an angel’s.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the high priest asked Stephen, “Are these accusations true?”
speaker: Narrator

text: This was Stephen’s reply: “Brothers and fathers, listen to me. Our glorious God appeared to our ancestor Abraham in Mesopotamia before he settled in Haran.
speaker: Narrator

text: God told him, ‘Leave your native land and your relatives, and come into the land that I will show you.’
speaker: Narrator

text: So Abraham left the land of the Chaldeans and lived in Haran until his father died. Then God brought him here to the land where you now live.
speaker: Narrator

text: “But God gave him no inheritance here, not even one square foot of land. God did promise, however, that eventually the whole land would belong to Abraham and his descendants—even though he had no children yet.
speaker: Narrator

text: God also told him that his descendants would live in a foreign land, where they would be oppressed as slaves for 400 years.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘But I will punish the nation that enslaves them,’ God said, ‘and in the end they will come out and worship me here in this place.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “God also gave Abraham the covenant of circumcision at that time. So when Abraham became the father of Isaac, he circumcised him on the eighth day. And the practice was continued when Isaac became the father of Jacob, and when Jacob became the father of the twelve patriarchs of the Israelite nation.
speaker: Narrator

text: “These patriarchs were jealous of their brother Joseph, and they sold him to be a slave in Egypt. But God was with him
speaker: Narrator

text: and rescued him from all his troubles. And God gave him favor before Pharaoh, king of Egypt. God also gave Joseph unusual wisdom, so that Pharaoh appointed him governor over all of Egypt and put him in charge of the palace.
speaker: Narrator

text: “But a famine came upon Egypt and Canaan. There was great misery, and our ancestors ran out of food.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jacob heard that there was still grain in Egypt, so he sent his sons—our ancestors—to buy some.
speaker: Narrator

text: The second time they went, Joseph revealed his identity to his brothers, and they were introduced to Pharaoh.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Joseph sent for his father, Jacob, and all his relatives to come to Egypt, seventy-five persons in all.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Jacob went to Egypt. He died there, as did our ancestors.
speaker: Narrator

text: Their bodies were taken to Shechem and buried in the tomb Abraham had bought for a certain price from Hamor’s sons in Shechem.
speaker: Narrator

text: “As the time drew near when God would fulfill his promise to Abraham, the number of our people in Egypt greatly increased.
speaker: Narrator

text: But then a new king came to the throne of Egypt who knew nothing about Joseph.
speaker: Narrator

text: This king exploited our people and oppressed them, forcing parents to abandon their newborn babies so they would die.
speaker: Narrator

text: “At that time Moses was born—a beautiful child in God’s eyes. His parents cared for him at home for three months.
speaker: Narrator

text: When they had to abandon him, Pharaoh’s daughter adopted him and raised him as her own son.
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses was taught all the wisdom of the Egyptians, and he was powerful in both speech and action.
speaker: Narrator

text: “One day when Moses was forty years old, he decided to visit his relatives, the people of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: He saw an Egyptian mistreating an Israelite. So Moses came to the man’s defense and avenged him, killing the Egyptian.
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses assumed his fellow Israelites would realize that God had sent him to rescue them, but they didn’t.
speaker: Narrator

text: “The next day he visited them again and saw two men of Israel fighting. He tried to be a peacemaker. ‘Men,’ he said, ‘you are brothers. Why are you fighting each other?’
speaker: Narrator

text: “But the man in the wrong pushed Moses aside. ‘Who made you a ruler and judge over us?’ he asked.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘Are you going to kill me as you killed that Egyptian yesterday?’
speaker: Narrator

text: When Moses heard that, he fled the country and lived as a foreigner in the land of Midian. There his two sons were born.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Forty years later, in the desert near Mount Sinai, an angel appeared to Moses in the flame of a burning bush.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Moses saw it, he was amazed at the sight. As he went to take a closer look, the voice of the Lord called out to him,
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘I am the God of your ancestors—the God of Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob.’ Moses shook with terror and did not dare to look.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Then the Lord said to him, ‘Take off your sandals, for you are standing on holy ground.
speaker: Narrator

text: I have certainly seen the oppression of my people in Egypt. I have heard their groans and have come down to rescue them. Now go, for I am sending you back to Egypt.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “So God sent back the same man his people had previously rejected when they demanded, ‘Who made you a ruler and judge over us?’ Through the angel who appeared to him in the burning bush, God sent Moses to be their ruler and savior.
speaker: Narrator

text: And by means of many wonders and miraculous signs, he led them out of Egypt, through the Red Sea, and through the wilderness for forty years.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Moses himself told the people of Israel, ‘God will raise up for you a Prophet like me from among your own people.’
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses was with our ancestors, the assembly of God’s people in the wilderness, when the angel spoke to him at Mount Sinai. And there Moses received life-giving words to pass on to us.
speaker: Narrator

text: “But our ancestors refused to listen to Moses. They rejected him and wanted to return to Egypt.
speaker: Narrator

text: They told Aaron, ‘Make us some gods who can lead us, for we don’t know what has become of this Moses, who brought us out of Egypt.’
speaker: Narrator

text: So they made an idol shaped like a calf, and they sacrificed to it and celebrated over this thing they had made.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then God turned away from them and abandoned them to serve the stars of heaven as their gods! In the book of the prophets it is written,
‘Was it to me you were bringing sacrifices and offerings
    during those forty years in the wilderness, Israel?
speaker: Narrator

text:
No, you carried your pagan gods—
    the shrine of Molech,
    the star of your god Rephan,
    and the images you made to worship them.
So I will send you into exile
    as far away as Babylon.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “Our ancestors carried the Tabernacle with them through the wilderness. It was constructed according to the plan God had shown to Moses.
speaker: Narrator

text: Years later, when Joshua led our ancestors in battle against the nations that God drove out of this land, the Tabernacle was taken with them into their new territory. And it stayed there until the time of King David.
speaker: Narrator

text: “David found favor with God and asked for the privilege of building a permanent Temple for the God of Jacob.
speaker: Narrator

text: But it was Solomon who actually built it.
speaker: Narrator

text: However, the Most High doesn’t live in temples made by human hands. As the prophet says,
speaker: Narrator

text:
‘Heaven is my throne,
    and the earth is my footstool.
Could you build me a temple as good as that?’
    asks the Lord.
‘Could you build me such a resting place?
speaker: Narrator

text: Didn’t my hands make both heaven and earth?’
speaker: Narrator

text: “You stubborn people! You are heathen at heart and deaf to the truth. Must you forever resist the Holy Spirit? That’s what your ancestors did, and so do you!
speaker: Narrator

text: Name one prophet your ancestors didn’t persecute! They even killed the ones who predicted the coming of the Righteous One—the Messiah whom you betrayed and murdered.
speaker: Narrator

text: You deliberately disobeyed God’s law, even though you received it from the hands of angels.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Jewish leaders were infuriated by Stephen’s accusation, and they shook their fists at him in rage.
speaker: Narrator

text: But Stephen, full of the Holy Spirit, gazed steadily into heaven and saw the glory of God, and he saw Jesus standing in the place of honor at God’s right hand.
speaker: Narrator

text: And he told them, “Look, I see the heavens opened and the Son of Man standing in the place of honor at God’s right hand!”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then they put their hands over their ears and began shouting. They rushed at him
speaker: Narrator

text: and dragged him out of the city and began to stone him. His accusers took off their coats and laid them at the feet of a young man named Saul.
speaker: Narrator

text: As they stoned him, Stephen prayed, “Lord Jesus, receive my spirit.”
speaker: Narrator

text: He fell to his knees, shouting, “Lord, don’t charge them with this sin!” And with that, he died.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Saul was one of the witnesses, and he agreed completely with the killing of Stephen.
A great wave of persecution began that day, sweeping over the church in Jerusalem; and all the believers except the apostles were scattered through the regions of Judea and Samaria.
speaker: Narrator

text: (Some devout men came and buried Stephen with great mourning.)
speaker: Narrator

text: But Saul was going everywhere to destroy the church. He went from house to house, dragging out both men and women to throw them into prison.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the believers who were scattered preached the Good News about Jesus wherever they went.
speaker: Narrator

text: Philip, for example, went to the city of Samaria and told the people there about the Messiah.
speaker: Narrator

text: Crowds listened intently to Philip because they were eager to hear his message and see the miraculous signs he did.
speaker: Narrator

text: Many evil spirits were cast out, screaming as they left their victims. And many who had been paralyzed or lame were healed.
speaker: Narrator

text: So there was great joy in that city.
speaker: Narrator

text: A man named Simon had been a sorcerer there for many years, amazing the people of Samaria and claiming to be someone great.
speaker: Narrator

text: Everyone, from the least to the greatest, often spoke of him as “the Great One—the Power of God.”
speaker: Narrator

text: They listened closely to him because for a long time he had astounded them with his magic.
speaker: Narrator

text: But now the people believed Philip’s message of Good News concerning the Kingdom of God and the name of Jesus Christ. As a result, many men and women were baptized.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Simon himself believed and was baptized. He began following Philip wherever he went, and he was amazed by the signs and great miracles Philip performed.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the apostles in Jerusalem heard that the people of Samaria had accepted God’s message, they sent Peter and John there.
speaker: Narrator

text: As soon as they arrived, they prayed for these new believers to receive the Holy Spirit.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Holy Spirit had not yet come upon any of them, for they had only been baptized in the name of the Lord Jesus.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Peter and John laid their hands upon these believers, and they received the Holy Spirit.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Simon saw that the Spirit was given when the apostles laid their hands on people, he offered them money to buy this power.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Let me have this power, too,” he exclaimed, “so that when I lay my hands on people, they will receive the Holy Spirit!”
speaker: Narrator

text: But Peter replied, “May your money be destroyed with you for thinking God’s gift can be bought!
speaker: Narrator

text: You can have no part in this, for your heart is not right with God.
speaker: Narrator

text: Repent of your wickedness and pray to the Lord. Perhaps he will forgive your evil thoughts,
speaker: Narrator

text: for I can see that you are full of bitter jealousy and are held captive by sin.”
speaker: Narrator

text: “Pray to the Lord for me,” Simon exclaimed, “that these terrible things you’ve said won’t happen to me!”
speaker: Narrator

text: After testifying and preaching the word of the Lord in Samaria, Peter and John returned to Jerusalem. And they stopped in many Samaritan villages along the way to preach the Good News.
speaker: Narrator

text: As for Philip, an angel of the Lord said to him, “Go south down the desert road that runs from Jerusalem to Gaza.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So he started out, and he met the treasurer of Ethiopia, a eunuch of great authority under the Kandake, the queen of Ethiopia. The eunuch had gone to Jerusalem to worship,
speaker: Narrator

text: and he was now returning. Seated in his carriage, he was reading aloud from the book of the prophet Isaiah.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Holy Spirit said to Philip, “Go over and walk along beside the carriage.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Philip ran over and heard the man reading from the prophet Isaiah. Philip asked, “Do you understand what you are reading?”
speaker: Narrator

text: The man replied, “How can I, unless someone instructs me?” And he urged Philip to come up into the carriage and sit with him.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The passage of Scripture he had been reading was this:
“He was led like a sheep to the slaughter.
    And as a lamb is silent before the shearers,
    he did not open his mouth.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He was humiliated and received no justice.
    Who can speak of his descendants?
    For his life was taken from the earth.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The eunuch asked Philip, “Tell me, was the prophet talking about himself or someone else?”
speaker: Narrator

text: So beginning with this same Scripture, Philip told him the Good News about Jesus.
speaker: Narrator

text: As they rode along, they came to some water, and the eunuch said, “Look! There’s some water! Why can’t I be baptized?”
speaker: Narrator

text: He ordered the carriage to stop, and they went down into the water, and Philip baptized him.
speaker: Narrator

text: When they came up out of the water, the Spirit of the Lord snatched Philip away. The eunuch never saw him again but went on his way rejoicing.
speaker: Narrator

text: Meanwhile, Philip found himself farther north at the town of Azotus. He preached the Good News there and in every town along the way until he came to Caesarea.
speaker: Narrator

text: Meanwhile, Saul was uttering threats with every breath and was eager to kill the Lord’s followers. So he went to the high priest.
speaker: Narrator

text: He requested letters addressed to the synagogues in Damascus, asking for their cooperation in the arrest of any followers of the Way he found there. He wanted to bring them—both men and women—back to Jerusalem in chains.
speaker: Narrator

text: As he was approaching Damascus on this mission, a light from heaven suddenly shone down around him.
speaker: Narrator

text: He fell to the ground and heard a voice saying to him, “Saul! Saul! Why are you persecuting me?”
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Who are you, lord?” Saul asked.
And the voice replied, “I am Jesus, the one you are persecuting!
speaker: Narrator

text: Now get up and go into the city, and you will be told what you must do.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The men with Saul stood speechless, for they heard the sound of someone’s voice but saw no one!
speaker: Narrator

text: Saul picked himself up off the ground, but when he opened his eyes he was blind. So his companions led him by the hand to Damascus.
speaker: Narrator

text: He remained there blind for three days and did not eat or drink.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Now there was a believer in Damascus named Ananias. The Lord spoke to him in a vision, calling, “Ananias!”
“Yes, Lord!” he replied.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said, “Go over to Straight Street, to the house of Judas. When you get there, ask for a man from Tarsus named Saul. He is praying to me right now.
speaker: Narrator

text: I have shown him a vision of a man named Ananias coming in and laying hands on him so he can see again.”
speaker: Narrator

text: “But Lord,” exclaimed Ananias, “I’ve heard many people talk about the terrible things this man has done to the believers in Jerusalem!
speaker: Narrator

text: And he is authorized by the leading priests to arrest everyone who calls upon your name.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But the Lord said, “Go, for Saul is my chosen instrument to take my message to the Gentiles and to kings, as well as to the people of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: And I will show him how much he must suffer for my name’s sake.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Ananias went and found Saul. He laid his hands on him and said, “Brother Saul, the Lord Jesus, who appeared to you on the road, has sent me so that you might regain your sight and be filled with the Holy Spirit.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Instantly something like scales fell from Saul’s eyes, and he regained his sight. Then he got up and was baptized.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Afterward he ate some food and regained his strength.
Saul stayed with the believers in Damascus for a few days.
speaker: Narrator

text: And immediately he began preaching about Jesus in the synagogues, saying, “He is indeed the Son of God!”
speaker: Narrator

text: All who heard him were amazed. “Isn’t this the same man who caused such devastation among Jesus’ followers in Jerusalem?” they asked. “And didn’t he come here to arrest them and take them in chains to the leading priests?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Saul’s preaching became more and more powerful, and the Jews in Damascus couldn’t refute his proofs that Jesus was indeed the Messiah.
speaker: Narrator

text: After a while some of the Jews plotted together to kill him.
speaker: Narrator

text: They were watching for him day and night at the city gate so they could murder him, but Saul was told about their plot.
speaker: Narrator

text: So during the night, some of the other believers lowered him in a large basket through an opening in the city wall.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Saul arrived in Jerusalem, he tried to meet with the believers, but they were all afraid of him. They did not believe he had truly become a believer!
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Barnabas brought him to the apostles and told them how Saul had seen the Lord on the way to Damascus and how the Lord had spoken to Saul. He also told them that Saul had preached boldly in the name of Jesus in Damascus.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Saul stayed with the apostles and went all around Jerusalem with them, preaching boldly in the name of the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: He debated with some Greek-speaking Jews, but they tried to murder him.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the believers heard about this, they took him down to Caesarea and sent him away to Tarsus, his hometown.
speaker: Narrator

text: The church then had peace throughout Judea, Galilee, and Samaria, and it became stronger as the believers lived in the fear of the Lord. And with the encouragement of the Holy Spirit, it also grew in numbers.
speaker: Narrator

text: Meanwhile, Peter traveled from place to place, and he came down to visit the believers in the town of Lydda.
speaker: Narrator

text: There he met a man named Aeneas, who had been paralyzed and bedridden for eight years.
speaker: Narrator

text: Peter said to him, “Aeneas, Jesus Christ heals you! Get up, and roll up your sleeping mat!” And he was healed instantly.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the whole population of Lydda and Sharon saw Aeneas walking around, and they turned to the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: There was a believer in Joppa named Tabitha (which in Greek is Dorcas). She was always doing kind things for others and helping the poor.
speaker: Narrator

text: About this time she became ill and died. Her body was washed for burial and laid in an upstairs room.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the believers had heard that Peter was nearby at Lydda, so they sent two men to beg him, “Please come as soon as possible!”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Peter returned with them; and as soon as he arrived, they took him to the upstairs room. The room was filled with widows who were weeping and showing him the coats and other clothes Dorcas had made for them.
speaker: Narrator

text: But Peter asked them all to leave the room; then he knelt and prayed. Turning to the body he said, “Get up, Tabitha.” And she opened her eyes! When she saw Peter, she sat up!
speaker: Narrator

text: He gave her his hand and helped her up. Then he called in the widows and all the believers, and he presented her to them alive.
speaker: Narrator

text: The news spread through the whole town, and many believed in the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: And Peter stayed a long time in Joppa, living with Simon, a tanner of hides.
speaker: Narrator

text: In Caesarea there lived a Roman army officer named Cornelius, who was a captain of the Italian Regiment.
speaker: Narrator

text: He was a devout, God-fearing man, as was everyone in his household. He gave generously to the poor and prayed regularly to God.
speaker: Narrator

text: One afternoon about three o’clock, he had a vision in which he saw an angel of God coming toward him. “Cornelius!” the angel said.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Cornelius stared at him in terror. “What is it, sir?” he asked the angel.
And the angel replied, “Your prayers and gifts to the poor have been received by God as an offering!
speaker: Narrator

text: Now send some men to Joppa, and summon a man named Simon Peter.
speaker: Narrator

text: He is staying with Simon, a tanner who lives near the seashore.”
speaker: Narrator

text: As soon as the angel was gone, Cornelius called two of his household servants and a devout soldier, one of his personal attendants.
speaker: Narrator

text: He told them what had happened and sent them off to Joppa.
speaker: Narrator

text: The next day as Cornelius’s messengers were nearing the town, Peter went up on the flat roof to pray. It was about noon,
speaker: Narrator

text: and he was hungry. But while a meal was being prepared, he fell into a trance.
speaker: Narrator

text: He saw the sky open, and something like a large sheet was let down by its four corners.
speaker: Narrator

text: In the sheet were all sorts of animals, reptiles, and birds.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then a voice said to him, “Get up, Peter; kill and eat them.”
speaker: Narrator

text: “No, Lord,” Peter declared. “I have never eaten anything that our Jewish laws have declared impure and unclean.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But the voice spoke again: “Do not call something unclean if God has made it clean.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The same vision was repeated three times. Then the sheet was suddenly pulled up to heaven.
speaker: Narrator

text: Peter was very perplexed. What could the vision mean? Just then the men sent by Cornelius found Simon’s house. Standing outside the gate,
speaker: Narrator

text: they asked if a man named Simon Peter was staying there.
speaker: Narrator

text: Meanwhile, as Peter was puzzling over the vision, the Holy Spirit said to him, “Three men have come looking for you.
speaker: Narrator

text: Get up, go downstairs, and go with them without hesitation. Don’t worry, for I have sent them.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Peter went down and said, “I’m the man you are looking for. Why have you come?”
speaker: Narrator

text: They said, “We were sent by Cornelius, a Roman officer. He is a devout and God-fearing man, well respected by all the Jews. A holy angel instructed him to summon you to his house so that he can hear your message.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Peter invited the men to stay for the night. The next day he went with them, accompanied by some of the brothers from Joppa.
speaker: Narrator

text: They arrived in Caesarea the following day. Cornelius was waiting for them and had called together his relatives and close friends.
speaker: Narrator

text: As Peter entered his home, Cornelius fell at his feet and worshiped him.
speaker: Narrator

text: But Peter pulled him up and said, “Stand up! I’m a human being just like you!”
speaker: Narrator

text: So they talked together and went inside, where many others were assembled.
speaker: Narrator

text: Peter told them, “You know it is against our laws for a Jewish man to enter a Gentile home like this or to associate with you. But God has shown me that I should no longer think of anyone as impure or unclean.
speaker: Narrator

text: So I came without objection as soon as I was sent for. Now tell me why you sent for me.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Cornelius replied, “Four days ago I was praying in my house about this same time, three o’clock in the afternoon. Suddenly, a man in dazzling clothes was standing in front of me.
speaker: Narrator

text: He told me, ‘Cornelius, your prayer has been heard, and your gifts to the poor have been noticed by God!
speaker: Narrator

text: Now send messengers to Joppa, and summon a man named Simon Peter. He is staying in the home of Simon, a tanner who lives near the seashore.’
speaker: Narrator

text: So I sent for you at once, and it was good of you to come. Now we are all here, waiting before God to hear the message the Lord has given you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Peter replied, “I see very clearly that God shows no favoritism.
speaker: Narrator

text: In every nation he accepts those who fear him and do what is right.
speaker: Narrator

text: This is the message of Good News for the people of Israel—that there is peace with God through Jesus Christ, who is Lord of all.
speaker: Narrator

text: You know what happened throughout Judea, beginning in Galilee, after John began preaching his message of baptism.
speaker: Narrator

text: And you know that God anointed Jesus of Nazareth with the Holy Spirit and with power. Then Jesus went around doing good and healing all who were oppressed by the devil, for God was with him.
speaker: Narrator

text: “And we apostles are witnesses of all he did throughout Judea and in Jerusalem. They put him to death by hanging him on a cross,
speaker: Narrator

text: but God raised him to life on the third day. Then God allowed him to appear,
speaker: Narrator

text: not to the general public, but to us whom God had chosen in advance to be his witnesses. We were those who ate and drank with him after he rose from the dead.
speaker: Narrator

text: And he ordered us to preach everywhere and to testify that Jesus is the one appointed by God to be the judge of all—the living and the dead.
speaker: Narrator

text: He is the one all the prophets testified about, saying that everyone who believes in him will have their sins forgiven through his name.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Even as Peter was saying these things, the Holy Spirit fell upon all who were listening to the message.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Jewish believers who came with Peter were amazed that the gift of the Holy Spirit had been poured out on the Gentiles, too.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For they heard them speaking in other tongues and praising God.
Then Peter asked,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Can anyone object to their being baptized, now that they have received the Holy Spirit just as we did?”
speaker: Narrator

text: So he gave orders for them to be baptized in the name of Jesus Christ. Afterward Cornelius asked him to stay with them for several days.
speaker: Narrator

text: Soon the news reached the apostles and other believers in Judea that the Gentiles had received the word of God.
speaker: Narrator

text: But when Peter arrived back in Jerusalem, the Jewish believers criticized him.
speaker: Narrator

text: “You entered the home of Gentiles and even ate with them!” they said.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Peter told them exactly what had happened.
speaker: Narrator

text: “I was in the town of Joppa,” he said, “and while I was praying, I went into a trance and saw a vision. Something like a large sheet was let down by its four corners from the sky. And it came right down to me.
speaker: Narrator

text: When I looked inside the sheet, I saw all sorts of tame and wild animals, reptiles, and birds.
speaker: Narrator

text: And I heard a voice say, ‘Get up, Peter; kill and eat them.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “‘No, Lord,’ I replied. ‘I have never eaten anything that our Jewish laws have declared impure or unclean.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “But the voice from heaven spoke again: ‘Do not call something unclean if God has made it clean.’
speaker: Narrator

text: This happened three times before the sheet and all it contained was pulled back up to heaven.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Just then three men who had been sent from Caesarea arrived at the house where we were staying.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Holy Spirit told me to go with them and not to worry that they were Gentiles. These six brothers here accompanied me, and we soon entered the home of the man who had sent for us.
speaker: Narrator

text: He told us how an angel had appeared to him in his home and had told him, ‘Send messengers to Joppa, and summon a man named Simon Peter.
speaker: Narrator

text: He will tell you how you and everyone in your household can be saved!’
speaker: Narrator

text: “As I began to speak,” Peter continued, “the Holy Spirit fell on them, just as he fell on us at the beginning.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then I thought of the Lord’s words when he said, ‘John baptized with water, but you will be baptized with the Holy Spirit.’
speaker: Narrator

text: And since God gave these Gentiles the same gift he gave us when we believed in the Lord Jesus Christ, who was I to stand in God’s way?”
speaker: Narrator

text: When the others heard this, they stopped objecting and began praising God. They said, “We can see that God has also given the Gentiles the privilege of repenting of their sins and receiving eternal life.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Meanwhile, the believers who had been scattered during the persecution after Stephen’s death traveled as far as Phoenicia, Cyprus, and Antioch of Syria. They preached the word of God, but only to Jews.
speaker: Narrator

text: However, some of the believers who went to Antioch from Cyprus and Cyrene began preaching to the Gentiles about the Lord Jesus.
speaker: Narrator

text: The power of the Lord was with them, and a large number of these Gentiles believed and turned to the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the church at Jerusalem heard what had happened, they sent Barnabas to Antioch.
speaker: Narrator

text: When he arrived and saw this evidence of God’s blessing, he was filled with joy, and he encouraged the believers to stay true to the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: Barnabas was a good man, full of the Holy Spirit and strong in faith. And many people were brought to the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Barnabas went on to Tarsus to look for Saul.
speaker: Narrator

text: When he found him, he brought him back to Antioch. Both of them stayed there with the church for a full year, teaching large crowds of people. (It was at Antioch that the believers were first called Christians.)
speaker: Narrator

text: During this time some prophets traveled from Jerusalem to Antioch.
speaker: Narrator

text: One of them named Agabus stood up in one of the meetings and predicted by the Spirit that a great famine was coming upon the entire Roman world. (This was fulfilled during the reign of Claudius.)
speaker: Narrator

text: So the believers in Antioch decided to send relief to the brothers and sisters in Judea, everyone giving as much as they could.
speaker: Narrator

text: This they did, entrusting their gifts to Barnabas and Saul to take to the elders of the church in Jerusalem.
speaker: Narrator

text: About that time King Herod Agrippa began to persecute some believers in the church.
speaker: Narrator

text: He had the apostle James (John’s brother) killed with a sword.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Herod saw how much this pleased the Jewish people, he also arrested Peter. (This took place during the Passover celebration.)
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he imprisoned him, placing him under the guard of four squads of four soldiers each. Herod intended to bring Peter out for public trial after the Passover.
speaker: Narrator

text: But while Peter was in prison, the church prayed very earnestly for him.
speaker: Narrator

text: The night before Peter was to be placed on trial, he was asleep, fastened with two chains between two soldiers. Others stood guard at the prison gate.
speaker: Narrator

text: Suddenly, there was a bright light in the cell, and an angel of the Lord stood before Peter. The angel struck him on the side to awaken him and said, “Quick! Get up!” And the chains fell off his wrists.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the angel told him, “Get dressed and put on your sandals.” And he did. “Now put on your coat and follow me,” the angel ordered.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Peter left the cell, following the angel. But all the time he thought it was a vision. He didn’t realize it was actually happening.
speaker: Narrator

text: They passed the first and second guard posts and came to the iron gate leading to the city, and this opened for them all by itself. So they passed through and started walking down the street, and then the angel suddenly left him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Peter finally came to his senses. “It’s really true!” he said. “The Lord has sent his angel and saved me from Herod and from what the Jewish leaders had planned to do to me!”
speaker: Narrator

text: When he realized this, he went to the home of Mary, the mother of John Mark, where many were gathered for prayer.
speaker: Narrator

text: He knocked at the door in the gate, and a servant girl named Rhoda came to open it.
speaker: Narrator

text: When she recognized Peter’s voice, she was so overjoyed that, instead of opening the door, she ran back inside and told everyone, “Peter is standing at the door!”
speaker: Narrator

text: “You’re out of your mind!” they said. When she insisted, they decided, “It must be his angel.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Meanwhile, Peter continued knocking. When they finally opened the door and saw him, they were amazed.
speaker: Narrator

text: He motioned for them to quiet down and told them how the Lord had led him out of prison. “Tell James and the other brothers what happened,” he said. And then he went to another place.
speaker: Narrator

text: At dawn there was a great commotion among the soldiers about what had happened to Peter.
speaker: Narrator

text: Herod Agrippa ordered a thorough search for him. When he couldn’t be found, Herod interrogated the guards and sentenced them to death. Afterward Herod left Judea to stay in Caesarea for a while.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now Herod was very angry with the people of Tyre and Sidon. So they sent a delegation to make peace with him because their cities were dependent upon Herod’s country for food. The delegates won the support of Blastus, Herod’s personal assistant,
speaker: Narrator

text: and an appointment with Herod was granted. When the day arrived, Herod put on his royal robes, sat on his throne, and made a speech to them.
speaker: Narrator

text: The people gave him a great ovation, shouting, “It’s the voice of a god, not of a man!”
speaker: Narrator

text: Instantly, an angel of the Lord struck Herod with a sickness, because he accepted the people’s worship instead of giving the glory to God. So he was consumed with worms and died.
speaker: Narrator

text: Meanwhile, the word of God continued to spread, and there were many new believers.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Barnabas and Saul had finished their mission to Jerusalem, they returned, taking John Mark with them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Among the prophets and teachers of the church at Antioch of Syria were Barnabas, Simeon (called “the black man”), Lucius (from Cyrene), Manaen (the childhood companion of King Herod Antipas), and Saul.
speaker: Narrator

text: One day as these men were worshiping the Lord and fasting, the Holy Spirit said, “Appoint Barnabas and Saul for the special work to which I have called them.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So after more fasting and prayer, the men laid their hands on them and sent them on their way.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Barnabas and Saul were sent out by the Holy Spirit. They went down to the seaport of Seleucia and then sailed for the island of Cyprus.
speaker: Narrator

text: There, in the town of Salamis, they went to the Jewish synagogues and preached the word of God. John Mark went with them as their assistant.
speaker: Narrator

text: Afterward they traveled from town to town across the entire island until finally they reached Paphos, where they met a Jewish sorcerer, a false prophet named Bar-Jesus.
speaker: Narrator

text: He had attached himself to the governor, Sergius Paulus, who was an intelligent man. The governor invited Barnabas and Saul to visit him, for he wanted to hear the word of God.
speaker: Narrator

text: But Elymas, the sorcerer (as his name means in Greek), interfered and urged the governor to pay no attention to what Barnabas and Saul said. He was trying to keep the governor from believing.
speaker: Narrator

text: Saul, also known as Paul, was filled with the Holy Spirit, and he looked the sorcerer in the eye.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he said, “You son of the devil, full of every sort of deceit and fraud, and enemy of all that is good! Will you never stop perverting the true ways of the Lord?
speaker: Narrator

text: Watch now, for the Lord has laid his hand of punishment upon you, and you will be struck blind. You will not see the sunlight for some time.” Instantly mist and darkness came over the man’s eyes, and he began groping around begging for someone to take his hand and lead him.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the governor saw what had happened, he became a believer, for he was astonished at the teaching about the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: Paul and his companions then left Paphos by ship for Pamphylia, landing at the port town of Perga. There John Mark left them and returned to Jerusalem.
speaker: Narrator

text:
But Paul and Barnabas traveled inland to Antioch of Pisidia.
On the Sabbath they went to the synagogue for the services.
speaker: Narrator

text: After the usual readings from the books of Moses and the prophets, those in charge of the service sent them this message: “Brothers, if you have any word of encouragement for the people, come and give it.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Paul stood, lifted his hand to quiet them, and started speaking. “Men of Israel,” he said, “and you God-fearing Gentiles, listen to me.
speaker: Narrator

text: “The God of this nation of Israel chose our ancestors and made them multiply and grow strong during their stay in Egypt. Then with a powerful arm he led them out of their slavery.
speaker: Narrator

text: He put up with them through forty years of wandering in the wilderness.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he destroyed seven nations in Canaan and gave their land to Israel as an inheritance.
speaker: Narrator

text:
All this took about 450 years.
“After that, God gave them judges to rule until the time of Samuel the prophet.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the people begged for a king, and God gave them Saul son of Kish, a man of the tribe of Benjamin, who reigned for forty years.
speaker: Narrator

text: But God removed Saul and replaced him with David, a man about whom God said, ‘I have found David son of Jesse, a man after my own heart. He will do everything I want him to do.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “And it is one of King David’s descendants, Jesus, who is God’s promised Savior of Israel!
speaker: Narrator

text: Before he came, John the Baptist preached that all the people of Israel needed to repent of their sins and turn to God and be baptized.
speaker: Narrator

text: As John was finishing his ministry he asked, ‘Do you think I am the Messiah? No, I am not! But he is coming soon—and I’m not even worthy to be his slave and untie the sandals on his feet.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “Brothers—you sons of Abraham, and also you God-fearing Gentiles—this message of salvation has been sent to us!
speaker: Narrator

text: The people in Jerusalem and their leaders did not recognize Jesus as the one the prophets had spoken about. Instead, they condemned him, and in doing this they fulfilled the prophets’ words that are read every Sabbath.
speaker: Narrator

text: They found no legal reason to execute him, but they asked Pilate to have him killed anyway.
speaker: Narrator

text: “When they had done all that the prophecies said about him, they took him down from the cross and placed him in a tomb.
speaker: Narrator

text: But God raised him from the dead!
speaker: Narrator

text: And over a period of many days he appeared to those who had gone with him from Galilee to Jerusalem. They are now his witnesses to the people of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: “And now we are here to bring you this Good News. The promise was made to our ancestors,
speaker: Narrator

text:
and God has now fulfilled it for us, their descendants, by raising Jesus. This is what the second psalm says about Jesus:
‘You are my Son.
    Today I have become your Father.’
speaker: Narrator

text: For God had promised to raise him from the dead, not leaving him to rot in the grave. He said, ‘I will give you the sacred blessings I promised to David.’
speaker: Narrator

text: Another psalm explains it more fully: ‘You will not allow your Holy One to rot in the grave.’
speaker: Narrator

text: This is not a reference to David, for after David had done the will of God in his own generation, he died and was buried with his ancestors, and his body decayed.
speaker: Narrator

text: No, it was a reference to someone else—someone whom God raised and whose body did not decay.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Brothers, listen! We are here to proclaim that through this man Jesus there is forgiveness for your sins.
speaker: Narrator

text: Everyone who believes in him is made right in God’s sight—something the law of Moses could never do.
speaker: Narrator

text: Be careful! Don’t let the prophets’ words apply to you. For they said,
speaker: Narrator

text:
‘Look, you mockers,
    be amazed and die!
For I am doing something in your own day,
    something you wouldn’t believe
    even if someone told you about it.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: As Paul and Barnabas left the synagogue that day, the people begged them to speak about these things again the next week.
speaker: Narrator

text: Many Jews and devout converts to Judaism followed Paul and Barnabas, and the two men urged them to continue to rely on the grace of God.
speaker: Narrator

text: The following week almost the entire city turned out to hear them preach the word of the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: But when some of the Jews saw the crowds, they were jealous; so they slandered Paul and argued against whatever he said.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Paul and Barnabas spoke out boldly and declared, “It was necessary that we first preach the word of God to you Jews. But since you have rejected it and judged yourselves unworthy of eternal life, we will offer it to the Gentiles.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For the Lord gave us this command when he said,
‘I have made you a light to the Gentiles,
    to bring salvation to the farthest corners of the earth.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: When the Gentiles heard this, they were very glad and thanked the Lord for his message; and all who were chosen for eternal life became believers.
speaker: Narrator

text: So the Lord’s message spread throughout that region.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Jews stirred up the influential religious women and the leaders of the city, and they incited a mob against Paul and Barnabas and ran them out of town.
speaker: Narrator

text: So they shook the dust from their feet as a sign of rejection and went to the town of Iconium.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the believers were filled with joy and with the Holy Spirit.
speaker: Narrator

text: The same thing happened in Iconium. Paul and Barnabas went to the Jewish synagogue and preached with such power that a great number of both Jews and Greeks became believers.
speaker: Narrator

text: Some of the Jews, however, spurned God’s message and poisoned the minds of the Gentiles against Paul and Barnabas.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the apostles stayed there a long time, preaching boldly about the grace of the Lord. And the Lord proved their message was true by giving them power to do miraculous signs and wonders.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the people of the town were divided in their opinion about them. Some sided with the Jews, and some with the apostles.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then a mob of Gentiles and Jews, along with their leaders, decided to attack and stone them.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the apostles learned of it, they fled to the region of Lycaonia—to the towns of Lystra and Derbe and the surrounding area.
speaker: Narrator

text: And there they preached the Good News.
speaker: Narrator

text: While they were at Lystra, Paul and Barnabas came upon a man with crippled feet. He had been that way from birth, so he had never walked. He was sitting
speaker: Narrator

text: and listening as Paul preached. Looking straight at him, Paul realized he had faith to be healed.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Paul called to him in a loud voice, “Stand up!” And the man jumped to his feet and started walking.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the crowd saw what Paul had done, they shouted in their local dialect, “These men are gods in human form!”
speaker: Narrator

text: They decided that Barnabas was the Greek god Zeus and that Paul was Hermes, since he was the chief speaker.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now the temple of Zeus was located just outside the town. So the priest of the temple and the crowd brought bulls and wreaths of flowers to the town gates, and they prepared to offer sacrifices to the apostles.
speaker: Narrator

text: But when the apostles Barnabas and Paul heard what was happening, they tore their clothing in dismay and ran out among the people, shouting,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Friends, why are you doing this? We are merely human beings—just like you! We have come to bring you the Good News that you should turn from these worthless things and turn to the living God, who made heaven and earth, the sea, and everything in them.
speaker: Narrator

text: In the past he permitted all the nations to go their own ways,
speaker: Narrator

text: but he never left them without evidence of himself and his goodness. For instance, he sends you rain and good crops and gives you food and joyful hearts.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But even with these words, Paul and Barnabas could scarcely restrain the people from sacrificing to them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then some Jews arrived from Antioch and Iconium and won the crowds to their side. They stoned Paul and dragged him out of town, thinking he was dead.
speaker: Narrator

text: But as the believers gathered around him, he got up and went back into the town. The next day he left with Barnabas for Derbe.
speaker: Narrator

text: After preaching the Good News in Derbe and making many disciples, Paul and Barnabas returned to Lystra, Iconium, and Antioch of Pisidia,
speaker: Narrator

text: where they strengthened the believers. They encouraged them to continue in the faith, reminding them that we must suffer many hardships to enter the Kingdom of God.
speaker: Narrator

text: Paul and Barnabas also appointed elders in every church. With prayer and fasting, they turned the elders over to the care of the Lord, in whom they had put their trust.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then they traveled back through Pisidia to Pamphylia.
speaker: Narrator

text: They preached the word in Perga, then went down to Attalia.
speaker: Narrator

text: Finally, they returned by ship to Antioch of Syria, where their journey had begun. The believers there had entrusted them to the grace of God to do the work they had now completed.
speaker: Narrator

text: Upon arriving in Antioch, they called the church together and reported everything God had done through them and how he had opened the door of faith to the Gentiles, too.
speaker: Narrator

text: And they stayed there with the believers for a long time.
speaker: Narrator

text: While Paul and Barnabas were at Antioch of Syria, some men from Judea arrived and began to teach the believers: “Unless you are circumcised as required by the law of Moses, you cannot be saved.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Paul and Barnabas disagreed with them, arguing vehemently. Finally, the church decided to send Paul and Barnabas to Jerusalem, accompanied by some local believers, to talk to the apostles and elders about this question.
speaker: Narrator

text: The church sent the delegates to Jerusalem, and they stopped along the way in Phoenicia and Samaria to visit the believers. They told them—much to everyone’s joy—that the Gentiles, too, were being converted.
speaker: Narrator

text: When they arrived in Jerusalem, Barnabas and Paul were welcomed by the whole church, including the apostles and elders. They reported everything God had done through them.
speaker: Narrator

text: But then some of the believers who belonged to the sect of the Pharisees stood up and insisted, “The Gentile converts must be circumcised and required to follow the law of Moses.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So the apostles and elders met together to resolve this issue.
speaker: Narrator

text: At the meeting, after a long discussion, Peter stood and addressed them as follows: “Brothers, you all know that God chose me from among you some time ago to preach to the Gentiles so that they could hear the Good News and believe.
speaker: Narrator

text: God knows people’s hearts, and he confirmed that he accepts Gentiles by giving them the Holy Spirit, just as he did to us.
speaker: Narrator

text: He made no distinction between us and them, for he cleansed their hearts through faith.
speaker: Narrator

text: So why are you now challenging God by burdening the Gentile believers with a yoke that neither we nor our ancestors were able to bear?
speaker: Narrator

text: We believe that we are all saved the same way, by the undeserved grace of the Lord Jesus.”
speaker: Narrator
