text: Everyone listened quietly as Barnabas and Paul told about the miraculous signs and wonders God had done through them among the Gentiles.
speaker: Narrator

text: When they had finished, James stood and said, “Brothers, listen to me.
speaker: Narrator

text: Peter has told you about the time God first visited the Gentiles to take from them a people for himself.
speaker: Narrator

text: And this conversion of Gentiles is exactly what the prophets predicted. As it is written:
speaker: Narrator

text:
‘Afterward I will return
    and restore the fallen house of David.
I will rebuild its ruins
    and restore it,
speaker: Narrator

text:
so that the rest of humanity might seek the Lord,
    including the Gentiles—
    all those I have called to be mine.
The Lord has spoken—
speaker: Narrator

text: he who made these things known so long ago.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “And so my judgment is that we should not make it difficult for the Gentiles who are turning to God.
speaker: Narrator

text: Instead, we should write and tell them to abstain from eating food offered to idols, from sexual immorality, from eating the meat of strangled animals, and from consuming blood.
speaker: Narrator

text: For these laws of Moses have been preached in Jewish synagogues in every city on every Sabbath for many generations.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the apostles and elders together with the whole church in Jerusalem chose delegates, and they sent them to Antioch of Syria with Paul and Barnabas to report on this decision. The men chosen were two of the church leaders—Judas (also called Barsabbas) and Silas.
speaker: Narrator

text:
This is the letter they took with them:
“This letter is from the apostles and elders, your brothers in Jerusalem. It is written to the Gentile believers in Antioch, Syria, and Cilicia. Greetings!
speaker: Narrator

text: “We understand that some men from here have troubled you and upset you with their teaching, but we did not send them!
speaker: Narrator

text: So we decided, having come to complete agreement, to send you official representatives, along with our beloved Barnabas and Paul,
speaker: Narrator

text: who have risked their lives for the name of our Lord Jesus Christ.
speaker: Narrator

text: We are sending Judas and Silas to confirm what we have decided concerning your question.
speaker: Narrator

text: “For it seemed good to the Holy Spirit and to us to lay no greater burden on you than these few requirements:
speaker: Narrator

text: You must abstain from eating food offered to idols, from consuming blood or the meat of strangled animals, and from sexual immorality. If you do this, you will do well. Farewell.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The messengers went at once to Antioch, where they called a general meeting of the believers and delivered the letter.
speaker: Narrator

text: And there was great joy throughout the church that day as they read this encouraging message.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Judas and Silas, both being prophets, spoke at length to the believers, encouraging and strengthening their faith.
speaker: Narrator

text: They stayed for a while, and then the believers sent them back to the church in Jerusalem with a blessing of peace.
speaker: Narrator

text: Paul and Barnabas stayed in Antioch. They and many others taught and preached the word of the Lord there.
speaker: Narrator

text: After some time Paul said to Barnabas, “Let’s go back and visit each city where we previously preached the word of the Lord, to see how the new believers are doing.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Barnabas agreed and wanted to take along John Mark.
speaker: Narrator

text: But Paul disagreed strongly, since John Mark had deserted them in Pamphylia and had not continued with them in their work.
speaker: Narrator

text: Their disagreement was so sharp that they separated. Barnabas took John Mark with him and sailed for Cyprus.
speaker: Narrator

text: Paul chose Silas, and as he left, the believers entrusted him to the Lord’s gracious care.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he traveled throughout Syria and Cilicia, strengthening the churches there.
speaker: Narrator

text: Paul went first to Derbe and then to Lystra, where there was a young disciple named Timothy. His mother was a Jewish believer, but his father was a Greek.
speaker: Narrator

text: Timothy was well thought of by the believers in Lystra and Iconium,
speaker: Narrator

text: so Paul wanted him to join them on their journey. In deference to the Jews of the area, he arranged for Timothy to be circumcised before they left, for everyone knew that his father was a Greek.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then they went from town to town, instructing the believers to follow the decisions made by the apostles and elders in Jerusalem.
speaker: Narrator

text: So the churches were strengthened in their faith and grew larger every day.
speaker: Narrator

text: Next Paul and Silas traveled through the area of Phrygia and Galatia, because the Holy Spirit had prevented them from preaching the word in the province of Asia at that time.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then coming to the borders of Mysia, they headed north for the province of Bithynia, but again the Spirit of Jesus did not allow them to go there.
speaker: Narrator

text: So instead, they went on through Mysia to the seaport of Troas.
speaker: Narrator

text: That night Paul had a vision: A man from Macedonia in northern Greece was standing there, pleading with him, “Come over to Macedonia and help us!”
speaker: Narrator

text: So we decided to leave for Macedonia at once, having concluded that God was calling us to preach the Good News there.
speaker: Narrator

text: We boarded a boat at Troas and sailed straight across to the island of Samothrace, and the next day we landed at Neapolis.
speaker: Narrator

text: From there we reached Philippi, a major city of that district of Macedonia and a Roman colony. And we stayed there several days.
speaker: Narrator

text: On the Sabbath we went a little way outside the city to a riverbank, where we thought people would be meeting for prayer, and we sat down to speak with some women who had gathered there.
speaker: Narrator

text: One of them was Lydia from Thyatira, a merchant of expensive purple cloth, who worshiped God. As she listened to us, the Lord opened her heart, and she accepted what Paul was saying.
speaker: Narrator

text: She and her household were baptized, and she asked us to be her guests. “If you agree that I am a true believer in the Lord,” she said, “come and stay at my home.” And she urged us until we agreed.
speaker: Narrator

text: One day as we were going down to the place of prayer, we met a slave girl who had a spirit that enabled her to tell the future. She earned a lot of money for her masters by telling fortunes.
speaker: Narrator

text: She followed Paul and the rest of us, shouting, “These men are servants of the Most High God, and they have come to tell you how to be saved.”
speaker: Narrator

text: This went on day after day until Paul got so exasperated that he turned and said to the demon within her, “I command you in the name of Jesus Christ to come out of her.” And instantly it left her.
speaker: Narrator

text: Her masters’ hopes of wealth were now shattered, so they grabbed Paul and Silas and dragged them before the authorities at the marketplace.
speaker: Narrator

text: “The whole city is in an uproar because of these Jews!” they shouted to the city officials.
speaker: Narrator

text: “They are teaching customs that are illegal for us Romans to practice.”
speaker: Narrator

text: A mob quickly formed against Paul and Silas, and the city officials ordered them stripped and beaten with wooden rods.
speaker: Narrator

text: They were severely beaten, and then they were thrown into prison. The jailer was ordered to make sure they didn’t escape.
speaker: Narrator

text: So the jailer put them into the inner dungeon and clamped their feet in the stocks.
speaker: Narrator

text: Around midnight Paul and Silas were praying and singing hymns to God, and the other prisoners were listening.
speaker: Narrator

text: Suddenly, there was a massive earthquake, and the prison was shaken to its foundations. All the doors immediately flew open, and the chains of every prisoner fell off!
speaker: Narrator

text: The jailer woke up to see the prison doors wide open. He assumed the prisoners had escaped, so he drew his sword to kill himself.
speaker: Narrator

text: But Paul shouted to him, “Stop! Don’t kill yourself! We are all here!”
speaker: Narrator

text: The jailer called for lights and ran to the dungeon and fell down trembling before Paul and Silas.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he brought them out and asked, “Sirs, what must I do to be saved?”
speaker: Narrator

text: They replied, “Believe in the Lord Jesus and you will be saved, along with everyone in your household.”
speaker: Narrator

text: And they shared the word of the Lord with him and with all who lived in his household.
speaker: Narrator

text: Even at that hour of the night, the jailer cared for them and washed their wounds. Then he and everyone in his household were immediately baptized.
speaker: Narrator

text: He brought them into his house and set a meal before them, and he and his entire household rejoiced because they all believed in God.
speaker: Narrator

text: The next morning the city officials sent the police to tell the jailer, “Let those men go!”
speaker: Narrator

text: So the jailer told Paul, “The city officials have said you and Silas are free to leave. Go in peace.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But Paul replied, “They have publicly beaten us without a trial and put us in prison—and we are Roman citizens. So now they want us to leave secretly? Certainly not! Let them come themselves to release us!”
speaker: Narrator

text: When the police reported this, the city officials were alarmed to learn that Paul and Silas were Roman citizens.
speaker: Narrator

text: So they came to the jail and apologized to them. Then they brought them out and begged them to leave the city.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Paul and Silas left the prison, they returned to the home of Lydia. There they met with the believers and encouraged them once more. Then they left town.
speaker: Narrator

text: Paul and Silas then traveled through the towns of Amphipolis and Apollonia and came to Thessalonica, where there was a Jewish synagogue.
speaker: Narrator

text: As was Paul’s custom, he went to the synagogue service, and for three Sabbaths in a row he used the Scriptures to reason with the people.
speaker: Narrator

text: He explained the prophecies and proved that the Messiah must suffer and rise from the dead. He said, “This Jesus I’m telling you about is the Messiah.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Some of the Jews who listened were persuaded and joined Paul and Silas, along with many God-fearing Greek men and quite a few prominent women.
speaker: Narrator

text: But some of the Jews were jealous, so they gathered some troublemakers from the marketplace to form a mob and start a riot. They attacked the home of Jason, searching for Paul and Silas so they could drag them out to the crowd.
speaker: Narrator

text: Not finding them there, they dragged out Jason and some of the other believers instead and took them before the city council. “Paul and Silas have caused trouble all over the world,” they shouted, “and now they are here disturbing our city, too.
speaker: Narrator

text: And Jason has welcomed them into his home. They are all guilty of treason against Caesar, for they profess allegiance to another king, named Jesus.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The people of the city, as well as the city council, were thrown into turmoil by these reports.
speaker: Narrator

text: So the officials forced Jason and the other believers to post bond, and then they released them.
speaker: Narrator

text: That very night the believers sent Paul and Silas to Berea. When they arrived there, they went to the Jewish synagogue.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the people of Berea were more open-minded than those in Thessalonica, and they listened eagerly to Paul’s message. They searched the Scriptures day after day to see if Paul and Silas were teaching the truth.
speaker: Narrator

text: As a result, many Jews believed, as did many of the prominent Greek women and men.
speaker: Narrator

text: But when some Jews in Thessalonica learned that Paul was preaching the word of God in Berea, they went there and stirred up trouble.
speaker: Narrator

text: The believers acted at once, sending Paul on to the coast, while Silas and Timothy remained behind.
speaker: Narrator

text: Those escorting Paul went with him all the way to Athens; then they returned to Berea with instructions for Silas and Timothy to hurry and join him.
speaker: Narrator

text: While Paul was waiting for them in Athens, he was deeply troubled by all the idols he saw everywhere in the city.
speaker: Narrator

text: He went to the synagogue to reason with the Jews and the God-fearing Gentiles, and he spoke daily in the public square to all who happened to be there.
speaker: Narrator

text: He also had a debate with some of the Epicurean and Stoic philosophers. When he told them about Jesus and his resurrection, they said, “What’s this babbler trying to say with these strange ideas he’s picked up?” Others said, “He seems to be preaching about some foreign gods.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then they took him to the high council of the city. “Come and tell us about this new teaching,” they said.
speaker: Narrator

text: “You are saying some rather strange things, and we want to know what it’s all about.”
speaker: Narrator

text: (It should be explained that all the Athenians as well as the foreigners in Athens seemed to spend all their time discussing the latest ideas.)
speaker: Narrator

text: So Paul, standing before the council, addressed them as follows: “Men of Athens, I notice that you are very religious in every way,
speaker: Narrator

text: for as I was walking along I saw your many shrines. And one of your altars had this inscription on it: ‘To an Unknown God.’ This God, whom you worship without knowing, is the one I’m telling you about.
speaker: Narrator

text: “He is the God who made the world and everything in it. Since he is Lord of heaven and earth, he doesn’t live in man-made temples,
speaker: Narrator

text: and human hands can’t serve his needs—for he has no needs. He himself gives life and breath to everything, and he satisfies every need.
speaker: Narrator

text: From one man he created all the nations throughout the whole earth. He decided beforehand when they should rise and fall, and he determined their boundaries.
speaker: Narrator

text: “His purpose was for the nations to seek after God and perhaps feel their way toward him and find him—though he is not far from any one of us.
speaker: Narrator

text: For in him we live and move and exist. As some of your own poets have said, ‘We are his offspring.’
speaker: Narrator

text: And since this is true, we shouldn’t think of God as an idol designed by craftsmen from gold or silver or stone.
speaker: Narrator

text: “God overlooked people’s ignorance about these things in earlier times, but now he commands everyone everywhere to repent of their sins and turn to him.
speaker: Narrator

text: For he has set a day for judging the world with justice by the man he has appointed, and he proved to everyone who this is by raising him from the dead.”
speaker: Narrator

text: When they heard Paul speak about the resurrection of the dead, some laughed in contempt, but others said, “We want to hear more about this later.”
speaker: Narrator

text: That ended Paul’s discussion with them,
speaker: Narrator

text: but some joined him and became believers. Among them were Dionysius, a member of the council, a woman named Damaris, and others with them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Paul left Athens and went to Corinth.
speaker: Narrator

text: There he became acquainted with a Jew named Aquila, born in Pontus, who had recently arrived from Italy with his wife, Priscilla. They had left Italy when Claudius Caesar deported all Jews from Rome.
speaker: Narrator

text: Paul lived and worked with them, for they were tentmakers just as he was.
speaker: Narrator

text: Each Sabbath found Paul at the synagogue, trying to convince the Jews and Greeks alike.
speaker: Narrator

text: And after Silas and Timothy came down from Macedonia, Paul spent all his time preaching the word. He testified to the Jews that Jesus was the Messiah.
speaker: Narrator

text: But when they opposed and insulted him, Paul shook the dust from his clothes and said, “Your blood is upon your own heads—I am innocent. From now on I will go preach to the Gentiles.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he left and went to the home of Titius Justus, a Gentile who worshiped God and lived next door to the synagogue.
speaker: Narrator

text: Crispus, the leader of the synagogue, and everyone in his household believed in the Lord. Many others in Corinth also heard Paul, became believers, and were baptized.
speaker: Narrator

text: One night the Lord spoke to Paul in a vision and told him, “Don’t be afraid! Speak out! Don’t be silent!
speaker: Narrator

text: For I am with you, and no one will attack and harm you, for many people in this city belong to me.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Paul stayed there for the next year and a half, teaching the word of God.
speaker: Narrator

text: But when Gallio became governor of Achaia, some Jews rose up together against Paul and brought him before the governor for judgment.
speaker: Narrator

text: They accused Paul of “persuading people to worship God in ways that are contrary to our law.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But just as Paul started to make his defense, Gallio turned to Paul’s accusers and said, “Listen, you Jews, if this were a case involving some wrongdoing or a serious crime, I would have a reason to accept your case.
speaker: Narrator

text: But since it is merely a question of words and names and your Jewish law, take care of it yourselves. I refuse to judge such matters.”
speaker: Narrator

text: And he threw them out of the courtroom.
speaker: Narrator

text: The crowd then grabbed Sosthenes, the leader of the synagogue, and beat him right there in the courtroom. But Gallio paid no attention.
speaker: Narrator

text: Paul stayed in Corinth for some time after that, then said good-bye to the brothers and sisters and went to nearby Cenchrea. There he shaved his head according to Jewish custom, marking the end of a vow. Then he set sail for Syria, taking Priscilla and Aquila with him.
speaker: Narrator

text: They stopped first at the port of Ephesus, where Paul left the others behind. While he was there, he went to the synagogue to reason with the Jews.
speaker: Narrator

text: They asked him to stay longer, but he declined.
speaker: Narrator

text: As he left, however, he said, “I will come back later, God willing.” Then he set sail from Ephesus.
speaker: Narrator

text: The next stop was at the port of Caesarea. From there he went up and visited the church at Jerusalem and then went back to Antioch.
speaker: Narrator

text: After spending some time in Antioch, Paul went back through Galatia and Phrygia, visiting and strengthening all the believers.
speaker: Narrator

text: Meanwhile, a Jew named Apollos, an eloquent speaker who knew the Scriptures well, had arrived in Ephesus from Alexandria in Egypt.
speaker: Narrator

text: He had been taught the way of the Lord, and he taught others about Jesus with an enthusiastic spirit and with accuracy. However, he knew only about John’s baptism.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Priscilla and Aquila heard him preaching boldly in the synagogue, they took him aside and explained the way of God even more accurately.
speaker: Narrator

text: Apollos had been thinking about going to Achaia, and the brothers and sisters in Ephesus encouraged him to go. They wrote to the believers in Achaia, asking them to welcome him. When he arrived there, he proved to be of great benefit to those who, by God’s grace, had believed.
speaker: Narrator

text: He refuted the Jews with powerful arguments in public debate. Using the Scriptures, he explained to them that Jesus was the Messiah.
speaker: Narrator

text: While Apollos was in Corinth, Paul traveled through the interior regions until he reached Ephesus, on the coast, where he found several believers.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Did you receive the Holy Spirit when you believed?” he asked them.
“No,” they replied, “we haven’t even heard that there is a Holy Spirit.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Then what baptism did you experience?” he asked.
And they replied, “The baptism of John.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Paul said, “John’s baptism called for repentance from sin. But John himself told the people to believe in the one who would come later, meaning Jesus.”
speaker: Narrator

text: As soon as they heard this, they were baptized in the name of the Lord Jesus.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then when Paul laid his hands on them, the Holy Spirit came on them, and they spoke in other tongues and prophesied.
speaker: Narrator

text: There were about twelve men in all.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Paul went to the synagogue and preached boldly for the next three months, arguing persuasively about the Kingdom of God.
speaker: Narrator

text: But some became stubborn, rejecting his message and publicly speaking against the Way. So Paul left the synagogue and took the believers with him. Then he held daily discussions at the lecture hall of Tyrannus.
speaker: Narrator

text: This went on for the next two years, so that people throughout the province of Asia—both Jews and Greeks—heard the word of the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: God gave Paul the power to perform unusual miracles.
speaker: Narrator

text: When handkerchiefs or aprons that had merely touched his skin were placed on sick people, they were healed of their diseases, and evil spirits were expelled.
speaker: Narrator

text: A group of Jews was traveling from town to town casting out evil spirits. They tried to use the name of the Lord Jesus in their incantation, saying, “I command you in the name of Jesus, whom Paul preaches, to come out!”
speaker: Narrator

text: Seven sons of Sceva, a leading priest, were doing this.
speaker: Narrator

text: But one time when they tried it, the evil spirit replied, “I know Jesus, and I know Paul, but who are you?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the man with the evil spirit leaped on them, overpowered them, and attacked them with such violence that they fled from the house, naked and battered.
speaker: Narrator

text: The story of what happened spread quickly all through Ephesus, to Jews and Greeks alike. A solemn fear descended on the city, and the name of the Lord Jesus was greatly honored.
speaker: Narrator

text: Many who became believers confessed their sinful practices.
speaker: Narrator

text: A number of them who had been practicing sorcery brought their incantation books and burned them at a public bonfire. The value of the books was several million dollars.
speaker: Narrator

text: So the message about the Lord spread widely and had a powerful effect.
speaker: Narrator

text: Afterward Paul felt compelled by the Spirit to go over to Macedonia and Achaia before going to Jerusalem. “And after that,” he said, “I must go on to Rome!”
speaker: Narrator

text: He sent his two assistants, Timothy and Erastus, ahead to Macedonia while he stayed awhile longer in the province of Asia.
speaker: Narrator

text: About that time, serious trouble developed in Ephesus concerning the Way.
speaker: Narrator

text: It began with Demetrius, a silversmith who had a large business manufacturing silver shrines of the Greek goddess Artemis. He kept many craftsmen busy.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He called them together, along with others employed in similar trades, and addressed them as follows:
“Gentlemen, you know that our wealth comes from this business.
speaker: Narrator

text: But as you have seen and heard, this man Paul has persuaded many people that handmade gods aren’t really gods at all. And he’s done this not only here in Ephesus but throughout the entire province!
speaker: Narrator

text: Of course, I’m not just talking about the loss of public respect for our business. I’m also concerned that the temple of the great goddess Artemis will lose its influence and that Artemis—this magnificent goddess worshiped throughout the province of Asia and all around the world—will be robbed of her great prestige!”
speaker: Narrator

text: At this their anger boiled, and they began shouting, “Great is Artemis of the Ephesians!”
speaker: Narrator

text: Soon the whole city was filled with confusion. Everyone rushed to the amphitheater, dragging along Gaius and Aristarchus, who were Paul’s traveling companions from Macedonia.
speaker: Narrator

text: Paul wanted to go in, too, but the believers wouldn’t let him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Some of the officials of the province, friends of Paul, also sent a message to him, begging him not to risk his life by entering the amphitheater.
speaker: Narrator

text: Inside, the people were all shouting, some one thing and some another. Everything was in confusion. In fact, most of them didn’t even know why they were there.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Jews in the crowd pushed Alexander forward and told him to explain the situation. He motioned for silence and tried to speak.
speaker: Narrator

text: But when the crowd realized he was a Jew, they started shouting again and kept it up for about two hours: “Great is Artemis of the Ephesians! Great is Artemis of the Ephesians!”
speaker: Narrator

text: At last the mayor was able to quiet them down enough to speak. “Citizens of Ephesus,” he said. “Everyone knows that Ephesus is the official guardian of the temple of the great Artemis, whose image fell down to us from heaven.
speaker: Narrator

text: Since this is an undeniable fact, you should stay calm and not do anything rash.
speaker: Narrator

text: You have brought these men here, but they have stolen nothing from the temple and have not spoken against our goddess.
speaker: Narrator

text: “If Demetrius and the craftsmen have a case against them, the courts are in session and the officials can hear the case at once. Let them make formal charges.
speaker: Narrator

text: And if there are complaints about other matters, they can be settled in a legal assembly.
speaker: Narrator

text: I am afraid we are in danger of being charged with rioting by the Roman government, since there is no cause for all this commotion. And if Rome demands an explanation, we won’t know what to say.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he dismissed them, and they dispersed.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the uproar was over, Paul sent for the believers and encouraged them. Then he said good-bye and left for Macedonia.
speaker: Narrator

text: While there, he encouraged the believers in all the towns he passed through. Then he traveled down to Greece,
speaker: Narrator

text: where he stayed for three months. He was preparing to sail back to Syria when he discovered a plot by some Jews against his life, so he decided to return through Macedonia.
speaker: Narrator

text: Several men were traveling with him. They were Sopater son of Pyrrhus from Berea; Aristarchus and Secundus from Thessalonica; Gaius from Derbe; Timothy; and Tychicus and Trophimus from the province of Asia.
speaker: Narrator

text: They went on ahead and waited for us at Troas.
speaker: Narrator

text: After the Passover ended, we boarded a ship at Philippi in Macedonia and five days later joined them in Troas, where we stayed a week.
speaker: Narrator

text: On the first day of the week, we gathered with the local believers to share in the Lord’s Supper. Paul was preaching to them, and since he was leaving the next day, he kept talking until midnight.
speaker: Narrator

text: The upstairs room where we met was lighted with many flickering lamps.
speaker: Narrator

text: As Paul spoke on and on, a young man named Eutychus, sitting on the windowsill, became very drowsy. Finally, he fell sound asleep and dropped three stories to his death below.
speaker: Narrator

text: Paul went down, bent over him, and took him into his arms. “Don’t worry,” he said, “he’s alive!”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then they all went back upstairs, shared in the Lord’s Supper, and ate together. Paul continued talking to them until dawn, and then he left.
speaker: Narrator

text: Meanwhile, the young man was taken home alive and well, and everyone was greatly relieved.
speaker: Narrator

text: Paul went by land to Assos, where he had arranged for us to join him, while we traveled by ship.
speaker: Narrator

text: He joined us there, and we sailed together to Mitylene.
speaker: Narrator

text: The next day we sailed past the island of Kios. The following day we crossed to the island of Samos, and a day later we arrived at Miletus.
speaker: Narrator

text: Paul had decided to sail on past Ephesus, for he didn’t want to spend any more time in the province of Asia. He was hurrying to get to Jerusalem, if possible, in time for the Festival of Pentecost.
speaker: Narrator

text: But when we landed at Miletus, he sent a message to the elders of the church at Ephesus, asking them to come and meet him.
speaker: Narrator

text: When they arrived he declared, “You know that from the day I set foot in the province of Asia until now
speaker: Narrator

text: I have done the Lord’s work humbly and with many tears. I have endured the trials that came to me from the plots of the Jews.
speaker: Narrator

text: I never shrank back from telling you what you needed to hear, either publicly or in your homes.
speaker: Narrator

text: I have had one message for Jews and Greeks alike—the necessity of repenting from sin and turning to God, and of having faith in our Lord Jesus.
speaker: Narrator

text: “And now I am bound by the Spirit to go to Jerusalem. I don’t know what awaits me,
speaker: Narrator

text: except that the Holy Spirit tells me in city after city that jail and suffering lie ahead.
speaker: Narrator

text: But my life is worth nothing to me unless I use it for finishing the work assigned me by the Lord Jesus—the work of telling others the Good News about the wonderful grace of God.
speaker: Narrator

text: “And now I know that none of you to whom I have preached the Kingdom will ever see me again.
speaker: Narrator

text: I declare today that I have been faithful. If anyone suffers eternal death, it’s not my fault,
speaker: Narrator

text: for I didn’t shrink from declaring all that God wants you to know.
speaker: Narrator

text: “So guard yourselves and God’s people. Feed and shepherd God’s flock—his church, purchased with his own blood—over which the Holy Spirit has appointed you as leaders.
speaker: Narrator

text: I know that false teachers, like vicious wolves, will come in among you after I leave, not sparing the flock.
speaker: Narrator

text: Even some men from your own group will rise up and distort the truth in order to draw a following.
speaker: Narrator

text: Watch out! Remember the three years I was with you—my constant watch and care over you night and day, and my many tears for you.
speaker: Narrator

text: “And now I entrust you to God and the message of his grace that is able to build you up and give you an inheritance with all those he has set apart for himself.
speaker: Narrator

text: “I have never coveted anyone’s silver or gold or fine clothes.
speaker: Narrator

text: You know that these hands of mine have worked to supply my own needs and even the needs of those who were with me.
speaker: Narrator

text: And I have been a constant example of how you can help those in need by working hard. You should remember the words of the Lord Jesus: ‘It is more blessed to give than to receive.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: When he had finished speaking, he knelt and prayed with them.
speaker: Narrator

text: They all cried as they embraced and kissed him good-bye.
speaker: Narrator

text: They were sad most of all because he had said that they would never see him again. Then they escorted him down to the ship.
speaker: Narrator

text: After saying farewell to the Ephesian elders, we sailed straight to the island of Cos. The next day we reached Rhodes and then went to Patara.
speaker: Narrator

text: There we boarded a ship sailing for Phoenicia.
speaker: Narrator

text: We sighted the island of Cyprus, passed it on our left, and landed at the harbor of Tyre, in Syria, where the ship was to unload its cargo.
speaker: Narrator

text: We went ashore, found the local believers, and stayed with them a week. These believers prophesied through the Holy Spirit that Paul should not go on to Jerusalem.
speaker: Narrator

text: When we returned to the ship at the end of the week, the entire congregation, including women and children, left the city and came down to the shore with us. There we knelt, prayed,
speaker: Narrator

text: and said our farewells. Then we went aboard, and they returned home.
speaker: Narrator

text: The next stop after leaving Tyre was Ptolemais, where we greeted the brothers and sisters and stayed for one day.
speaker: Narrator

text: The next day we went on to Caesarea and stayed at the home of Philip the Evangelist, one of the seven men who had been chosen to distribute food.
speaker: Narrator

text: He had four unmarried daughters who had the gift of prophecy.
speaker: Narrator

text: Several days later a man named Agabus, who also had the gift of prophecy, arrived from Judea.
speaker: Narrator

text: He came over, took Paul’s belt, and bound his own feet and hands with it. Then he said, “The Holy Spirit declares, ‘So shall the owner of this belt be bound by the Jewish leaders in Jerusalem and turned over to the Gentiles.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: When we heard this, we and the local believers all begged Paul not to go on to Jerusalem.
speaker: Narrator

text: But he said, “Why all this weeping? You are breaking my heart! I am ready not only to be jailed at Jerusalem but even to die for the sake of the Lord Jesus.”
speaker: Narrator

text: When it was clear that we couldn’t persuade him, we gave up and said, “The Lord’s will be done.”
speaker: Narrator

text: After this we packed our things and left for Jerusalem.
speaker: Narrator

text: Some believers from Caesarea accompanied us, and they took us to the home of Mnason, a man originally from Cyprus and one of the early believers.
speaker: Narrator

text: When we arrived, the brothers and sisters in Jerusalem welcomed us warmly.
speaker: Narrator

text: The next day Paul went with us to meet with James, and all the elders of the Jerusalem church were present.
speaker: Narrator

text: After greeting them, Paul gave a detailed account of the things God had accomplished among the Gentiles through his ministry.
speaker: Narrator

text: After hearing this, they praised God. And then they said, “You know, dear brother, how many thousands of Jews have also believed, and they all follow the law of Moses very seriously.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the Jewish believers here in Jerusalem have been told that you are teaching all the Jews who live among the Gentiles to turn their backs on the laws of Moses. They’ve heard that you teach them not to circumcise their children or follow other Jewish customs.
speaker: Narrator

text: What should we do? They will certainly hear that you have come.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Here’s what we want you to do. We have four men here who have completed their vow.
speaker: Narrator

text: Go with them to the Temple and join them in the purification ceremony, paying for them to have their heads ritually shaved. Then everyone will know that the rumors are all false and that you yourself observe the Jewish laws.
speaker: Narrator

text: “As for the Gentile believers, they should do what we already told them in a letter: They should abstain from eating food offered to idols, from consuming blood or the meat of strangled animals, and from sexual immorality.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Paul went to the Temple the next day with the other men. They had already started the purification ritual, so he publicly announced the date when their vows would end and sacrifices would be offered for each of them.
speaker: Narrator

text: The seven days were almost ended when some Jews from the province of Asia saw Paul in the Temple and roused a mob against him. They grabbed him,
speaker: Narrator

text: yelling, “Men of Israel, help us! This is the man who preaches against our people everywhere and tells everybody to disobey the Jewish laws. He speaks against the Temple—and even defiles this holy place by bringing in Gentiles.”
speaker: Narrator

text: (For earlier that day they had seen him in the city with Trophimus, a Gentile from Ephesus, and they assumed Paul had taken him into the Temple.)
speaker: Narrator

text: The whole city was rocked by these accusations, and a great riot followed. Paul was grabbed and dragged out of the Temple, and immediately the gates were closed behind him.
speaker: Narrator

text: As they were trying to kill him, word reached the commander of the Roman regiment that all Jerusalem was in an uproar.
speaker: Narrator

text: He immediately called out his soldiers and officers and ran down among the crowd. When the mob saw the commander and the troops coming, they stopped beating Paul.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the commander arrested him and ordered him bound with two chains. He asked the crowd who he was and what he had done.
speaker: Narrator

text: Some shouted one thing and some another. Since he couldn’t find out the truth in all the uproar and confusion, he ordered that Paul be taken to the fortress.
speaker: Narrator

text: As Paul reached the stairs, the mob grew so violent the soldiers had to lift him to their shoulders to protect him.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the crowd followed behind, shouting, “Kill him, kill him!”
speaker: Narrator

text:
As Paul was about to be taken inside, he said to the commander, “May I have a word with you?”
“Do you know Greek?” the commander asked, surprised.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Aren’t you the Egyptian who led a rebellion some time ago and took 4,000 members of the Assassins out into the desert?”
speaker: Narrator

text: “No,” Paul replied, “I am a Jew and a citizen of Tarsus in Cilicia, which is an important city. Please, let me talk to these people.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The commander agreed, so Paul stood on the stairs and motioned to the people to be quiet. Soon a deep silence enveloped the crowd, and he addressed them in their own language, Aramaic.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Brothers and esteemed fathers,” Paul said, “listen to me as I offer my defense.”
speaker: Narrator

text: When they heard him speaking in their own language, the silence was even greater.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Paul said, “I am a Jew, born in Tarsus, a city in Cilicia, and I was brought up and educated here in Jerusalem under Gamaliel. As his student, I was carefully trained in our Jewish laws and customs. I became very zealous to honor God in everything I did, just like all of you today.
speaker: Narrator

text: And I persecuted the followers of the Way, hounding some to death, arresting both men and women and throwing them in prison.
speaker: Narrator

text: The high priest and the whole council of elders can testify that this is so. For I received letters from them to our Jewish brothers in Damascus, authorizing me to bring the followers of the Way from there to Jerusalem, in chains, to be punished.
speaker: Narrator

text: “As I was on the road, approaching Damascus about noon, a very bright light from heaven suddenly shone down around me.
speaker: Narrator

text: I fell to the ground and heard a voice saying to me, ‘Saul, Saul, why are you persecuting me?’
speaker: Narrator

text:
“‘Who are you, lord?’ I asked.
“And the voice replied, ‘I am Jesus the Nazarene, the one you are persecuting.’
speaker: Narrator

text: The people with me saw the light but didn’t understand the voice speaking to me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“I asked, ‘What should I do, Lord?’
“And the Lord told me, ‘Get up and go into Damascus, and there you will be told everything you are to do.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “I was blinded by the intense light and had to be led by the hand to Damascus by my companions.
speaker: Narrator

text: A man named Ananias lived there. He was a godly man, deeply devoted to the law, and well regarded by all the Jews of Damascus.
speaker: Narrator

text: He came and stood beside me and said, ‘Brother Saul, regain your sight.’ And that very moment I could see him!
speaker: Narrator

text: “Then he told me, ‘The God of our ancestors has chosen you to know his will and to see the Righteous One and hear him speak.
speaker: Narrator

text: For you are to be his witness, telling everyone what you have seen and heard.
speaker: Narrator

text: What are you waiting for? Get up and be baptized. Have your sins washed away by calling on the name of the Lord.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “After I returned to Jerusalem, I was praying in the Temple and fell into a trance.
speaker: Narrator

text: I saw a vision of Jesus saying to me, ‘Hurry! Leave Jerusalem, for the people here won’t accept your testimony about me.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “‘But Lord,’ I argued, ‘they certainly know that in every synagogue I imprisoned and beat those who believed in you.
speaker: Narrator

text: And I was in complete agreement when your witness Stephen was killed. I stood by and kept the coats they took off when they stoned him.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “But the Lord said to me, ‘Go, for I will send you far away to the Gentiles!’”
speaker: Narrator

text: The crowd listened until Paul said that word. Then they all began to shout, “Away with such a fellow! He isn’t fit to live!”
speaker: Narrator

text: They yelled, threw off their coats, and tossed handfuls of dust into the air.
speaker: Narrator

text: The commander brought Paul inside and ordered him lashed with whips to make him confess his crime. He wanted to find out why the crowd had become so furious.
speaker: Narrator

text: When they tied Paul down to lash him, Paul said to the officer standing there, “Is it legal for you to whip a Roman citizen who hasn’t even been tried?”
speaker: Narrator

text: When the officer heard this, he went to the commander and asked, “What are you doing? This man is a Roman citizen!”
speaker: Narrator

text:
So the commander went over and asked Paul, “Tell me, are you a Roman citizen?”
“Yes, I certainly am,” Paul replied.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“I am, too,” the commander muttered, “and it cost me plenty!”
Paul answered, “But I am a citizen by birth!”
speaker: Narrator

text: The soldiers who were about to interrogate Paul quickly withdrew when they heard he was a Roman citizen, and the commander was frightened because he had ordered him bound and whipped.
speaker: Narrator

text: The next day the commander ordered the leading priests into session with the Jewish high council. He wanted to find out what the trouble was all about, so he released Paul to have him stand before them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Gazing intently at the high council, Paul began: “Brothers, I have always lived before God with a clear conscience!”
speaker: Narrator

text: Instantly Ananias the high priest commanded those close to Paul to slap him on the mouth.
speaker: Narrator

text: But Paul said to him, “God will slap you, you corrupt hypocrite! What kind of judge are you to break the law yourself by ordering me struck like that?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Those standing near Paul said to him, “Do you dare to insult God’s high priest?”
speaker: Narrator

text: “I’m sorry, brothers. I didn’t realize he was the high priest,” Paul replied, “for the Scriptures say, ‘You must not speak evil of any of your rulers.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: Paul realized that some members of the high council were Sadducees and some were Pharisees, so he shouted, “Brothers, I am a Pharisee, as were my ancestors! And I am on trial because my hope is in the resurrection of the dead!”
speaker: Narrator

text: This divided the council—the Pharisees against the Sadducees—
speaker: Narrator

text: for the Sadducees say there is no resurrection or angels or spirits, but the Pharisees believe in all of these.
speaker: Narrator

text: So there was a great uproar. Some of the teachers of religious law who were Pharisees jumped up and began to argue forcefully. “We see nothing wrong with him,” they shouted. “Perhaps a spirit or an angel spoke to him.”
speaker: Narrator

text: As the conflict grew more violent, the commander was afraid they would tear Paul apart. So he ordered his soldiers to go and rescue him by force and take him back to the fortress.
speaker: Narrator

text: That night the Lord appeared to Paul and said, “Be encouraged, Paul. Just as you have been a witness to me here in Jerusalem, you must preach the Good News in Rome as well.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The next morning a group of Jews got together and bound themselves with an oath not to eat or drink until they had killed Paul.
speaker: Narrator

text: There were more than forty of them in the conspiracy.
speaker: Narrator

text: They went to the leading priests and elders and told them, “We have bound ourselves with an oath to eat nothing until we have killed Paul.
speaker: Narrator

text: So you and the high council should ask the commander to bring Paul back to the council again. Pretend you want to examine his case more fully. We will kill him on the way.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But Paul’s nephew—his sister’s son—heard of their plan and went to the fortress and told Paul.
speaker: Narrator

text: Paul called for one of the Roman officers and said, “Take this young man to the commander. He has something important to tell him.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So the officer did, explaining, “Paul, the prisoner, called me over and asked me to bring this young man to you because he has something to tell you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The commander took his hand, led him aside, and asked, “What is it you want to tell me?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Paul’s nephew told him, “Some Jews are going to ask you to bring Paul before the high council tomorrow, pretending they want to get some more information.
speaker: Narrator

text: But don’t do it! There are more than forty men hiding along the way ready to ambush him. They have vowed not to eat or drink anything until they have killed him. They are ready now, just waiting for your consent.”
speaker: Narrator

text: “Don’t let anyone know you told me this,” the commander warned the young man.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the commander called two of his officers and ordered, “Get 200 soldiers ready to leave for Caesarea at nine o’clock tonight. Also take 200 spearmen and 70 mounted troops.
speaker: Narrator

text: Provide horses for Paul to ride, and get him safely to Governor Felix.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he wrote this letter to the governor:
speaker: Narrator

text: “From Claudius Lysias, to his Excellency, Governor Felix: Greetings!
speaker: Narrator

text: “This man was seized by some Jews, and they were about to kill him when I arrived with the troops. When I learned that he was a Roman citizen, I removed him to safety.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then I took him to their high council to try to learn the basis of the accusations against him.
speaker: Narrator

text: I soon discovered the charge was something regarding their religious law—certainly nothing worthy of imprisonment or death.
speaker: Narrator

text: But when I was informed of a plot to kill him, I immediately sent him on to you. I have told his accusers to bring their charges before you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So that night, as ordered, the soldiers took Paul as far as Antipatris.
speaker: Narrator

text: They returned to the fortress the next morning, while the mounted troops took him on to Caesarea.
speaker: Narrator

text: When they arrived in Caesarea, they presented Paul and the letter to Governor Felix.
speaker: Narrator

text: He read it and then asked Paul what province he was from. “Cilicia,” Paul answered.
speaker: Narrator

text: “I will hear your case myself when your accusers arrive,” the governor told him. Then the governor ordered him kept in the prison at Herod’s headquarters.
speaker: Narrator

text: Five days later Ananias, the high priest, arrived with some of the Jewish elders and the lawyer Tertullus, to present their case against Paul to the governor.
speaker: Narrator

text:
When Paul was called in, Tertullus presented the charges against Paul in the following address to the governor:
“You have provided a long period of peace for us Jews and with foresight have enacted reforms for us.
speaker: Narrator

text: For all of this, Your Excellency, we are very grateful to you.
speaker: Narrator

text: But I don’t want to bore you, so please give me your attention for only a moment.
speaker: Narrator

text: We have found this man to be a troublemaker who is constantly stirring up riots among the Jews all over the world. He is a ringleader of the cult known as the Nazarenes.
speaker: Narrator

text: Furthermore, he was trying to desecrate the Temple when we arrested him.
speaker: Narrator

text: You can find out the truth of our accusations by examining him yourself.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the other Jews chimed in, declaring that everything Tertullus said was true.
speaker: Narrator

text: The governor then motioned for Paul to speak. Paul said, “I know, sir, that you have been a judge of Jewish affairs for many years, so I gladly present my defense before you.
speaker: Narrator

text: You can quickly discover that I arrived in Jerusalem no more than twelve days ago to worship at the Temple.
speaker: Narrator

text: My accusers never found me arguing with anyone in the Temple, nor stirring up a riot in any synagogue or on the streets of the city.
speaker: Narrator

text: These men cannot prove the things they accuse me of doing.
speaker: Narrator

text: “But I admit that I follow the Way, which they call a cult. I worship the God of our ancestors, and I firmly believe the Jewish law and everything written in the prophets.
speaker: Narrator

text: I have the same hope in God that these men have, that he will raise both the righteous and the unrighteous.
speaker: Narrator

text: Because of this, I always try to maintain a clear conscience before God and all people.
speaker: Narrator

text: “After several years away, I returned to Jerusalem with money to aid my people and to offer sacrifices to God.
speaker: Narrator

text: My accusers saw me in the Temple as I was completing a purification ceremony. There was no crowd around me and no rioting.
speaker: Narrator

text: But some Jews from the province of Asia were there—and they ought to be here to bring charges if they have anything against me!
speaker: Narrator

text: Ask these men here what crime the Jewish high council found me guilty of,
speaker: Narrator

text: except for the one time I shouted out, ‘I am on trial before you today because I believe in the resurrection of the dead!’”
speaker: Narrator

text: At that point Felix, who was quite familiar with the Way, adjourned the hearing and said, “Wait until Lysias, the garrison commander, arrives. Then I will decide the case.”
speaker: Narrator

text: He ordered an officer to keep Paul in custody but to give him some freedom and allow his friends to visit him and take care of his needs.
speaker: Narrator

text: A few days later Felix came back with his wife, Drusilla, who was Jewish. Sending for Paul, they listened as he told them about faith in Christ Jesus.
speaker: Narrator

text: As he reasoned with them about righteousness and self-control and the coming day of judgment, Felix became frightened. “Go away for now,” he replied. “When it is more convenient, I’ll call for you again.”
speaker: Narrator

text: He also hoped that Paul would bribe him, so he sent for him quite often and talked with him.
speaker: Narrator

text: After two years went by in this way, Felix was succeeded by Porcius Festus. And because Felix wanted to gain favor with the Jewish people, he left Paul in prison.
speaker: Narrator

text: Three days after Festus arrived in Caesarea to take over his new responsibilities, he left for Jerusalem,
speaker: Narrator

text: where the leading priests and other Jewish leaders met with him and made their accusations against Paul.
speaker: Narrator

text: They asked Festus as a favor to transfer Paul to Jerusalem (planning to ambush and kill him on the way).
speaker: Narrator

text: But Festus replied that Paul was at Caesarea and he himself would be returning there soon.
speaker: Narrator

text: So he said, “Those of you in authority can return with me. If Paul has done anything wrong, you can make your accusations.”
speaker: Narrator

text: About eight or ten days later Festus returned to Caesarea, and on the following day he took his seat in court and ordered that Paul be brought in.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Paul arrived, the Jewish leaders from Jerusalem gathered around and made many serious accusations they couldn’t prove.
speaker: Narrator

text: Paul denied the charges. “I am not guilty of any crime against the Jewish laws or the Temple or the Roman government,” he said.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Festus, wanting to please the Jews, asked him, “Are you willing to go to Jerusalem and stand trial before me there?”
speaker: Narrator

text: But Paul replied, “No! This is the official Roman court, so I ought to be tried right here. You know very well I am not guilty of harming the Jews.
speaker: Narrator

text: If I have done something worthy of death, I don’t refuse to die. But if I am innocent, no one has a right to turn me over to these men to kill me. I appeal to Caesar!”
speaker: Narrator

text: Festus conferred with his advisers and then replied, “Very well! You have appealed to Caesar, and to Caesar you will go!”
speaker: Narrator

text: A few days later King Agrippa arrived with his sister, Bernice, to pay their respects to Festus.
speaker: Narrator

text: During their stay of several days, Festus discussed Paul’s case with the king. “There is a prisoner here,” he told him, “whose case was left for me by Felix.
speaker: Narrator

text: When I was in Jerusalem, the leading priests and Jewish elders pressed charges against him and asked me to condemn him.
speaker: Narrator

text: I pointed out to them that Roman law does not convict people without a trial. They must be given an opportunity to confront their accusers and defend themselves.
speaker: Narrator

text: “When his accusers came here for the trial, I didn’t delay. I called the case the very next day and ordered Paul brought in.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the accusations made against him weren’t any of the crimes I expected.
speaker: Narrator

text: Instead, it was something about their religion and a dead man named Jesus, who Paul insists is alive.
speaker: Narrator

text: I was at a loss to know how to investigate these things, so I asked him whether he would be willing to stand trial on these charges in Jerusalem.
speaker: Narrator

text: But Paul appealed to have his case decided by the emperor. So I ordered that he be held in custody until I could arrange to send him to Caesar.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
“I’d like to hear the man myself,” Agrippa said.
And Festus replied, “You will—tomorrow!”
speaker: Narrator

text: So the next day Agrippa and Bernice arrived at the auditorium with great pomp, accompanied by military officers and prominent men of the city. Festus ordered that Paul be brought in.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Festus said, “King Agrippa and all who are here, this is the man whose death is demanded by all the Jews, both here and in Jerusalem.
speaker: Narrator

text: But in my opinion he has done nothing deserving death. However, since he appealed his case to the emperor, I have decided to send him to Rome.
speaker: Narrator

text: “But what shall I write the emperor? For there is no clear charge against him. So I have brought him before all of you, and especially you, King Agrippa, so that after we examine him, I might have something to write.
speaker: Narrator

text: For it makes no sense to send a prisoner to the emperor without specifying the charges against him!”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then Agrippa said to Paul, “You may speak in your defense.”
So Paul, gesturing with his hand, started his defense:
speaker: Narrator

text: “I am fortunate, King Agrippa, that you are the one hearing my defense today against all these accusations made by the Jewish leaders,
speaker: Narrator

text: for I know you are an expert on all Jewish customs and controversies. Now please listen to me patiently!
speaker: Narrator

text: “As the Jewish leaders are well aware, I was given a thorough Jewish training from my earliest childhood among my own people and in Jerusalem.
speaker: Narrator

text: If they would admit it, they know that I have been a member of the Pharisees, the strictest sect of our religion.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now I am on trial because of my hope in the fulfillment of God’s promise made to our ancestors.
speaker: Narrator

text: In fact, that is why the twelve tribes of Israel zealously worship God night and day, and they share the same hope I have. Yet, Your Majesty, they accuse me for having this hope!
speaker: Narrator

text: Why does it seem incredible to any of you that God can raise the dead?
speaker: Narrator

text: “I used to believe that I ought to do everything I could to oppose the very name of Jesus the Nazarene.
speaker: Narrator

text: Indeed, I did just that in Jerusalem. Authorized by the leading priests, I caused many believers there to be sent to prison. And I cast my vote against them when they were condemned to death.
speaker: Narrator

text: Many times I had them punished in the synagogues to get them to curse Jesus. I was so violently opposed to them that I even chased them down in foreign cities.
speaker: Narrator

text: “One day I was on such a mission to Damascus, armed with the authority and commission of the leading priests.
speaker: Narrator

text: About noon, Your Majesty, as I was on the road, a light from heaven brighter than the sun shone down on me and my companions.
speaker: Narrator

text: We all fell down, and I heard a voice saying to me in Aramaic, ‘Saul, Saul, why are you persecuting me? It is useless for you to fight against my will.’
speaker: Narrator

text:
“‘Who are you, lord?’ I asked.
“And the Lord replied, ‘I am Jesus, the one you are persecuting.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now get to your feet! For I have appeared to you to appoint you as my servant and witness. Tell people that you have seen me, and tell them what I will show you in the future.
speaker: Narrator

text: And I will rescue you from both your own people and the Gentiles. Yes, I am sending you to the Gentiles
speaker: Narrator

text: to open their eyes, so they may turn from darkness to light and from the power of Satan to God. Then they will receive forgiveness for their sins and be given a place among God’s people, who are set apart by faith in me.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “And so, King Agrippa, I obeyed that vision from heaven.
speaker: Narrator

text: I preached first to those in Damascus, then in Jerusalem and throughout all Judea, and also to the Gentiles, that all must repent of their sins and turn to God—and prove they have changed by the good things they do.
speaker: Narrator

text: Some Jews arrested me in the Temple for preaching this, and they tried to kill me.
speaker: Narrator

text: But God has protected me right up to this present time so I can testify to everyone, from the least to the greatest. I teach nothing except what the prophets and Moses said would happen—
speaker: Narrator

text: that the Messiah would suffer and be the first to rise from the dead, and in this way announce God’s light to Jews and Gentiles alike.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Suddenly, Festus shouted, “Paul, you are insane. Too much study has made you crazy!”
speaker: Narrator

text: But Paul replied, “I am not insane, Most Excellent Festus. What I am saying is the sober truth.
speaker: Narrator

text: And King Agrippa knows about these things. I speak boldly, for I am sure these events are all familiar to him, for they were not done in a corner!
speaker: Narrator

text: King Agrippa, do you believe the prophets? I know you do—”
speaker: Narrator

text: Agrippa interrupted him. “Do you think you can persuade me to become a Christian so quickly?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Paul replied, “Whether quickly or not, I pray to God that both you and everyone here in this audience might become the same as I am, except for these chains.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the king, the governor, Bernice, and all the others stood and left.
speaker: Narrator

text: As they went out, they talked it over and agreed, “This man hasn’t done anything to deserve death or imprisonment.”
speaker: Narrator

text: And Agrippa said to Festus, “He could have been set free if he hadn’t appealed to Caesar.”
speaker: Narrator

text: When the time came, we set sail for Italy. Paul and several other prisoners were placed in the custody of a Roman officer named Julius, a captain of the Imperial Regiment.
speaker: Narrator

text: Aristarchus, a Macedonian from Thessalonica, was also with us. We left on a ship whose home port was Adramyttium on the northwest coast of the province of Asia; it was scheduled to make several stops at ports along the coast of the province.
speaker: Narrator

text: The next day when we docked at Sidon, Julius was very kind to Paul and let him go ashore to visit with friends so they could provide for his needs.
speaker: Narrator

text: Putting out to sea from there, we encountered strong headwinds that made it difficult to keep the ship on course, so we sailed north of Cyprus between the island and the mainland.
speaker: Narrator

text: Keeping to the open sea, we passed along the coast of Cilicia and Pamphylia, landing at Myra, in the province of Lycia.
speaker: Narrator

text: There the commanding officer found an Egyptian ship from Alexandria that was bound for Italy, and he put us on board.
speaker: Narrator

text: We had several days of slow sailing, and after great difficulty we finally neared Cnidus. But the wind was against us, so we sailed across to Crete and along the sheltered coast of the island, past the cape of Salmone.
speaker: Narrator

text: We struggled along the coast with great difficulty and finally arrived at Fair Havens, near the town of Lasea.
speaker: Narrator

text: We had lost a lot of time. The weather was becoming dangerous for sea travel because it was so late in the fall, and Paul spoke to the ship’s officers about it.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Men,” he said, “I believe there is trouble ahead if we go on—shipwreck, loss of cargo, and danger to our lives as well.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But the officer in charge of the prisoners listened more to the ship’s captain and the owner than to Paul.
speaker: Narrator

text: And since Fair Havens was an exposed harbor—a poor place to spend the winter—most of the crew wanted to go on to Phoenix, farther up the coast of Crete, and spend the winter there. Phoenix was a good harbor with only a southwest and northwest exposure.
speaker: Narrator

text: When a light wind began blowing from the south, the sailors thought they could make it. So they pulled up anchor and sailed close to the shore of Crete.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the weather changed abruptly, and a wind of typhoon strength (called a “northeaster”) burst across the island and blew us out to sea.
speaker: Narrator

text: The sailors couldn’t turn the ship into the wind, so they gave up and let it run before the gale.
speaker: Narrator

text: We sailed along the sheltered side of a small island named Cauda, where with great difficulty we hoisted aboard the lifeboat being towed behind us.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the sailors bound ropes around the hull of the ship to strengthen it. They were afraid of being driven across to the sandbars of Syrtis off the African coast, so they lowered the sea anchor to slow the ship and were driven before the wind.
speaker: Narrator

text: The next day, as gale-force winds continued to batter the ship, the crew began throwing the cargo overboard.
speaker: Narrator

text: The following day they even took some of the ship’s gear and threw it overboard.
speaker: Narrator

text: The terrible storm raged for many days, blotting out the sun and the stars, until at last all hope was gone.
speaker: Narrator

text: No one had eaten for a long time. Finally, Paul called the crew together and said, “Men, you should have listened to me in the first place and not left Crete. You would have avoided all this damage and loss.
speaker: Narrator

text: But take courage! None of you will lose your lives, even though the ship will go down.
speaker: Narrator

text: For last night an angel of the God to whom I belong and whom I serve stood beside me,
speaker: Narrator

text: and he said, ‘Don’t be afraid, Paul, for you will surely stand trial before Caesar! What’s more, God in his goodness has granted safety to everyone sailing with you.’
speaker: Narrator

text: So take courage! For I believe God. It will be just as he said.
speaker: Narrator

text: But we will be shipwrecked on an island.”
speaker: Narrator

text: About midnight on the fourteenth night of the storm, as we were being driven across the Sea of Adria, the sailors sensed land was near.
speaker: Narrator

text: They dropped a weighted line and found that the water was 120 feet deep. But a little later they measured again and found it was only 90 feet deep.
speaker: Narrator

text: At this rate they were afraid we would soon be driven against the rocks along the shore, so they threw out four anchors from the back of the ship and prayed for daylight.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the sailors tried to abandon the ship; they lowered the lifeboat as though they were going to put out anchors from the front of the ship.
speaker: Narrator

text: But Paul said to the commanding officer and the soldiers, “You will all die unless the sailors stay aboard.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So the soldiers cut the ropes to the lifeboat and let it drift away.
speaker: Narrator

text: Just as day was dawning, Paul urged everyone to eat. “You have been so worried that you haven’t touched food for two weeks,” he said.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Please eat something now for your own good. For not a hair of your heads will perish.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he took some bread, gave thanks to God before them all, and broke off a piece and ate it.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then everyone was encouraged and began to eat—
speaker: Narrator

text: all 276 of us who were on board.
speaker: Narrator

text: After eating, the crew lightened the ship further by throwing the cargo of wheat overboard.
speaker: Narrator

text: When morning dawned, they didn’t recognize the coastline, but they saw a bay with a beach and wondered if they could get to shore by running the ship aground.
speaker: Narrator

text: So they cut off the anchors and left them in the sea. Then they lowered the rudders, raised the foresail, and headed toward shore.
speaker: Narrator

text: But they hit a shoal and ran the ship aground too soon. The bow of the ship stuck fast, while the stern was repeatedly smashed by the force of the waves and began to break apart.
speaker: Narrator

text: The soldiers wanted to kill the prisoners to make sure they didn’t swim ashore and escape.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the commanding officer wanted to spare Paul, so he didn’t let them carry out their plan. Then he ordered all who could swim to jump overboard first and make for land.
speaker: Narrator

text: The others held on to planks or debris from the broken ship. So everyone escaped safely to shore.
speaker: Narrator

text: Once we were safe on shore, we learned that we were on the island of Malta.
speaker: Narrator

text: The people of the island were very kind to us. It was cold and rainy, so they built a fire on the shore to welcome us.
speaker: Narrator

text: As Paul gathered an armful of sticks and was laying them on the fire, a poisonous snake, driven out by the heat, bit him on the hand.
speaker: Narrator

text: The people of the island saw it hanging from his hand and said to each other, “A murderer, no doubt! Though he escaped the sea, justice will not permit him to live.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But Paul shook off the snake into the fire and was unharmed.
speaker: Narrator

text: The people waited for him to swell up or suddenly drop dead. But when they had waited a long time and saw that he wasn’t harmed, they changed their minds and decided he was a god.
speaker: Narrator

text: Near the shore where we landed was an estate belonging to Publius, the chief official of the island. He welcomed us and treated us kindly for three days.
speaker: Narrator

text: As it happened, Publius’s father was ill with fever and dysentery. Paul went in and prayed for him, and laying his hands on him, he healed him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then all the other sick people on the island came and were healed.
speaker: Narrator

text: As a result we were showered with honors, and when the time came to sail, people supplied us with everything we would need for the trip.
speaker: Narrator

text: It was three months after the shipwreck that we set sail on another ship that had wintered at the island—an Alexandrian ship with the twin gods as its figurehead.
speaker: Narrator

text: Our first stop was Syracuse, where we stayed three days.
speaker: Narrator

text: From there we sailed across to Rhegium. A day later a south wind began blowing, so the following day we sailed up the coast to Puteoli.
speaker: Narrator

text: There we found some believers, who invited us to spend a week with them. And so we came to Rome.
speaker: Narrator

text: The brothers and sisters in Rome had heard we were coming, and they came to meet us at the Forum on the Appian Way. Others joined us at The Three Taverns. When Paul saw them, he was encouraged and thanked God.
speaker: Narrator

text: When we arrived in Rome, Paul was permitted to have his own private lodging, though he was guarded by a soldier.
speaker: Narrator

text: Three days after Paul’s arrival, he called together the local Jewish leaders. He said to them, “Brothers, I was arrested in Jerusalem and handed over to the Roman government, even though I had done nothing against our people or the customs of our ancestors.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Romans tried me and wanted to release me, because they found no cause for the death sentence.
speaker: Narrator

text: But when the Jewish leaders protested the decision, I felt it necessary to appeal to Caesar, even though I had no desire to press charges against my own people.
speaker: Narrator

text: I asked you to come here today so we could get acquainted and so I could explain to you that I am bound with this chain because I believe that the hope of Israel—the Messiah—has already come.”
speaker: Narrator

text: They replied, “We have had no letters from Judea or reports against you from anyone who has come here.
speaker: Narrator

text: But we want to hear what you believe, for the only thing we know about this movement is that it is denounced everywhere.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So a time was set, and on that day a large number of people came to Paul’s lodging. He explained and testified about the Kingdom of God and tried to persuade them about Jesus from the Scriptures. Using the law of Moses and the books of the prophets, he spoke to them from morning until evening.
speaker: Narrator

text: Some were persuaded by the things he said, but others did not believe.
speaker: Narrator

text: And after they had argued back and forth among themselves, they left with this final word from Paul: “The Holy Spirit was right when he said to your ancestors through Isaiah the prophet,
speaker: Narrator

text:
‘Go and say to this people:
When you hear what I say,
    you will not understand.
When you see what I do,
    you will not comprehend.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For the hearts of these people are hardened,
    and their ears cannot hear,
    and they have closed their eyes—
so their eyes cannot see,
    and their ears cannot hear,
    and their hearts cannot understand,
and they cannot turn to me
    and let me heal them.’
speaker: Narrator

text: So I want you to know that this salvation from God has also been offered to the Gentiles, and they will accept it.”
speaker: Narrator

text: For the next two years, Paul lived in Rome at his own expense. He welcomed all who visited him,
speaker: Narrator

text: boldly proclaiming the Kingdom of God and teaching about the Lord Jesus Christ. And no one tried to stop him.
speaker: Narrator
